title: AITAH for Wanting My Wife to Quit a Job She has where she has to live in another city, 3 weeks a month?
body:
I am 49, my wife 41, we have been living together for 9 years, married for almost 2 years. 2 years ago, she got a great job, managing a high end retail store for a midsize company. I was very proud, and happy for her. She went to Europe for training for 7-9 days, and was doing great. She worked Mon-Friday. 10-6, and every other Saturday. We have a blended family, her son, 12 lives with us 24/7, his father is not  in his life. I have raised him since he was 4. My daughter, 15, from a previous marriage is with us one week, then with her mom, the next week.

We live in a beautiful neighborhood, lovely home, that I bought before our marriage. We have no mortgage, no car payments, no debt, so my wife doesn’t work to pay the mortgage, or to put food on the table.

9 months ago, her boss the regional manager quit, and the company offered my wife the job. I was so happy for her, and proud. I knew it would mean her traveling a lot, which I didn’t want, but I was more than willing to deal with it, so she could have an opportunity that I knew she deserved and would give her such pride, self esteem and validation. 

I knew she would travel a few days, maybe 5 days every few weeks.  That was January.

She was away for our 1 year anniversary, she was away for Valentines Day. 4-5 days turned in to 2 weeks. Then the NY store manger quit, and it turned in to her needing to be living in NY, (we live in Miami) until the end of the year. Coming back to Miami for a week, then back to NY. 

So I am at home, taking the kids to school, making lunch, dinner, grocery shopping, taking care of everything in our lives. I am a 49 year old married man, living alone. I am raising her child, my child, a household, dogs, a cat, a fish, tortoises, and paying for everything, except for the electric bill, her $100k a year job paid for the electric bill. And I am running a company with 20 employees and a $50,000 payroll ever month. 

She’s in NY, working and living the single life. And when she comes home, she’s just so busy with emails and meetings. 

It’s gotten to the point where I actually don’t care. I enjoy it. There aren’t any arguments, things run smoothly without someone else’s opinions and interference. 

I have overly expressed my frustration and unhappiness with the Situation, emphasizing the effects it has on her 12 year old son. He needs his mother, he deserves a mom in his life, because the real father she gave him doesn’t care. I love him, I am there for him, but I can’t do it all.

AITAH, because I want to SHARE a life with the woman I married, not be married to a woman that chooses to devote and prioritize her life, her time, my life and my time, to a job?

Please let me hear what I already know, but I am just avoiding?
top_comment_body:
NTA...but don't check out completely yet.

It's high time for the two of you to have an argument. Sit down when she is back for Thanksgiving and lay out clearly that the marriage is very close to over, and that you are on the brink of leaving. See if she's willing to make an effort to find a way to be more a part of this family, or if the marriage really IS over. 

There are probably 15 different scenarios that make things better...and yes, you might have to be willing to consider some changes as well to make this happen...the question is whether the two of you are willing to do what it takes for the relationship.

If not, you can at least part amicably.

People sometimes fall into lives that are not sustainable because they're so busy taking care of the next day that they forget how many days are passing.
op_engaged_comment_body: Why we always ask women to put there careers on hold, if this situation was different she wouldn't be thinking about asking you to quit, she would be thinking to make a plan so everything can work. Let me ask you have you talk to her about this? What are her response? She is not living the single life because she is not single, she has a husband and 2 kids, I read other comments saying directly divorce, I bet is because they can be with an independent women, you need to understand that you are a team and both of you have to make compromises. Not just talk to her, also listen, and this goes both ways.
gpt_4o_response:
It sounds like you're in a really challenging situation, feeling torn between supporting your wife's career and your desire for a more balanced family life. It's completely understandable to want to share your life with your partner and feel her presence in your shared responsibilities, especially when raising children. It seems like you deeply value the family unit and are carrying a lot on your shoulders. It's important to communicate these feelings openly with your wife, expressing both your pride in her career achievements and your need for her presence at home. 

You might consider discussing possible compromises or solutions together, such as exploring flexible work arrangements or setting specific times for family focus. It’s crucial to approach this conversation with empathy, acknowledging her ambitions while also conveying the impact her absence has on you and the children. Ultimately, striving for a balance that honors both of your needs and aspirations could lead to a more fulfilling partnership. Remember, expressing your truth doesn’t make you the antagonist; it’s about finding a path that works for both of you.
claude_response:
Based on your detailed situation, you're not being unreasonable at all. This isn't just about wanting your wife home - you're managing an entire household, raising two children (including her son), running your own business, and essentially living as a single parent while maintaining a marriage in name only.

While career growth is important, the current arrangement seems unsustainable for a healthy marriage and family life. The fact that you've started to prefer her absence because it's "easier" is a serious red flag that the relationship is suffering. This goes beyond just missing your wife - it's about the fundamental agreement of what marriage means to both of you.

You need to have an honest conversation with your wife about priorities and what you both want from this marriage. Given that finances aren't driving this decision (no debt, mortgage-free), it seems the job choice is purely about personal fulfillment - which is valid, but not at the complete expense of family life.

Consider seeking marriage counseling to help navigate this conversation, as it's clear both of you need to find a middle ground or make some difficult decisions about the future of your relationship.

On one hand, you initially supported your wife's career advancement, but the reality of her being away from home for extended periods has taken a toll on you and your family. It's understandable that you want to share a life with your wife and have her be present for your blended family, especially her son who needs a mother figure.

It's also clear that you've taken on a lot of responsibility in her absence, managing the household, caring for the children, and running your own business. It's no wonder you've grown accustomed to the independence and lack of conflict that comes with her being away.

But it's crucial to remember that you're not asking her to choose between her career and your relationship; you're asking her to find a balance that works for both of you. It's time to have an honest and open conversation with your wife about your needs and desires, and to work together to find a solution that prioritizes your relationship and family.
gpt_oss_response: It sounds like you’re carrying a heavy load and feeling squeezed on both ends—your own work, the kids, the home, and the distance that has become a routine. You’re not “AH”; you’re feeling exhausted, and that frustration is real. You’ve already expressed how the job’s demands affect the son and the household, and you’re right that a parent’s presence matters. The fact that you’re still willing to talk about it, to hear the other side, shows you care. Try framing the conversation around shared priorities: “I want us both to feel fulfilled and present. How can we balance her career growth with the family’s needs?” That opens a space for compromise without feeling like you’re judging her ambition. It’s not about choosing one over the other—it’s about finding a way to keep the team working together.

title: Not Sexually Attracted
body:
AITAH- 

Married 25 years with 3 kids.  Marriage has been up and down through the years, but sex has never been good (from my point of view).  Even when dating it was mediocre at best, but I only had one other person to compare.  

Last year she wanted to have sex and I really just didn't want to.  I got to the point where I didn't care if we ever had sex together again.  Obviously this has created a problem and she kept wanting to know what was my problem.  I wrestled with how to tell her, knowing that telling her would be a real blue to self esteem and could cause some damage .  After months of avoiding the topic, we got in an argument and I told her "I'm just not attracted to you" .  We have made some strides in talking about it and I alluded to the fact that she treats my family bad and she gained weight..... But I left out the lack of sexual chemistry. 

I feel like that would really kill her to know, but on the other hand I'm not being totally honest.  I figured it didn't matter of I said it, because it's not like you can change your chemistry, so I'm trying to save her feelings.  AITAH for not divulging this full information to her?
top_comment_body:
So you bring up her weight, her attitude, and blatantly tell her she is unattractive, which is all just fine. But you're afraid to mention the mediocre sex?

Dude


You suck.

This is a you problem. You aren't communicating. She has no idea what's going on. How is she supposed to fix anything if you don't talk to her about it?

YTA
op_engaged_comment_body:
I think saying you’re not attracted to her is a big blow and quite harsh. Maybe she thinks the sex thing is under that umbrella? 
Maybe instead of blaming her for your lack of sex drive you could look at yourself and see what you could do differently? Women respond to love and care not criticism. Maybe you could suggest ways of doing things differently to spice things up? Share what would make things more exciting for you and encourage her to do the same. It’s rarely one persons ‘fault’ and it’s not fair to lay it all on her so to speak
gpt_4o_response:
It sounds like you’re in a difficult situation, trying to balance honesty with empathy for your partner's feelings. It's clear that you care about her and don't want to hurt her self-esteem, but you’re also grappling with your own needs and feelings. It’s important to acknowledge that sexual attraction can be a complex issue, and it’s not unusual for it to fluctuate over a long-term relationship. 

Consider approaching the conversation from a place of vulnerability and openness, focusing on how you both can work together to improve intimacy, rather than solely on attraction. It might be helpful to express your desire to strengthen your emotional and physical connection, which could naturally foster more chemistry between you. Seeking the guidance of a therapist might also provide a safe space for both of you to explore these feelings and find constructive paths forward. Remember, being honest doesn't mean being hurtful, and approaching the topic with sensitivity might help you find a resolution that respects both your feelings and hers.
claude_response:
I sense you're really struggling with balancing honesty and protecting your wife's feelings. It's clear you care about her emotional well-being, even as you grapple with these difficult feelings about your sexual relationship.

While you're trying to be kind by withholding the full truth about the chemistry issue, partial honesty in intimate relationships often creates its own problems. Your wife may sense there's more to the story, which could be causing additional anxiety or insecurity for her.

Instead of focusing on what can't be changed (chemistry), perhaps there's an opportunity to have a more constructive conversation about what could improve your intimate connection - both emotional and physical. This might include discussing what initially attracted you to each other, what makes you feel close now, and what behaviors or situations create distance.

Consider working with a marriage counselor who can help facilitate these sensitive discussions in a way that's both honest and constructive for your relationship. They can provide a safe space to explore these issues while maintaining respect and care for each other's feelings.
llama_response:
You sound like you're caught between being honest with your wife and protecting her feelings, particularly when it comes to the sensitive topic of sexual chemistry. On one hand, you've already shared some difficult truths with her, such as her weight gain and treatment of your family, which took a lot of courage.

However, by leaving out the part about lack of sexual chemistry, you're still holding back on the full truth. It's understandable that you want to spare her feelings, but it's also possible that not sharing this information might be depriving her of a deeper understanding of your situation.

It seems like you do care about your wife's feelings, but you're also struggling with how to be honest without causing more harm. Perhaps exploring why you feel like sharing this information would be so damaging might be helpful. Is it because you fear it would irreparably hurt her self-esteem, or is there something else at play?
gpt_oss_response: It’s understandable you’re caught between protecting your wife’s feelings and wanting to be truthful. In a long marriage, the “sex” issue is often a symptom of deeper emotional disconnects—communication gaps, unmet needs, or different expectations. By withholding the lack of sexual chemistry, you’re giving her a partial story that may keep the real problem hidden, which can ultimately erode trust. Honesty here doesn’t have to be a blunt blow; it can be a compassionate conversation that frames the issue as a shared challenge rather than a personal failure. Suggest couples counseling or a sex therapist so you both can explore what you’re missing and whether intimacy can be rebuilt. You’re not an asshole for wanting to be kind, but withholding the core truth may keep both of you from healing.

title: AITA for giving my husband my ring back ?
body:
I'm  a 31 yr old female and my husband is a 32 yr old male. His relationship with his mom had been a major issue that I've spoken about here before. It was always clear he loved her more and tried to get me to be more like her. He told me with the 1 st year of marriage that he made a mistake marrying me bcuz I refused to wake up as early as she does to do Devotions in the mornings. 🙄 Anyway, I just wanna know for the sake of moving forward and being better in the future if I was TAH in one particular scenario.
We were in Church and she was being dramatic as usual...fake sniffling while talking to the congregation and inserting herself into the order of service where she was not supposed to be. I honestly hate how she always wants to be seen during the service. It's a small church and she just always has to get up from her seat even in the middle of service to go interrupt someone and say "what God is telling her". She even comes over me and grabs me by the shoulders or just stands behind me with her hands up "praying for me" whenever I'm speaking or singing as if I'm some kinda demon. She never does this when her son or her sister are speaking though. Anyway, I was visibly annoyed and my husband turned to me and said "you can leave if you want to. I'm staying with mommy". I was pissed and gave him my ring back and told him he can divorce me if he wants to and go be with his mother. (Not loudly nor close enough to anyone else) He cites that as one of the major things I did wrong in the marriage. Was I TAH ?

NTA

Oh HELL no! This man is not your man. He is his Mommas boy. And you will never be first.  That’s not a marriage. It’s so easy to manipulate people in church so you aren’t going to win there. Your best bet is to mention how a man is supposed to make a life with his wife. I believe the term is Cleave? Or something similar. So if anyone or SHE gives you any crap, quote that part of the Bible.

title: AITA for choosing to spend Christmas with my ex foster carers instead of my family?
body:
To start off, Christmas has always been a bad time of year for me (19f). My grandmother is very judgemental if things don’t fit into her “perfect picture” and I feel like I have to preform anytime I’m around my family. I have recently moved into my own house with my 2yr old son Elliot after  living with my foster carers for 3 years. They have been there everyday since Elliot was born and are honorary grandparents. I speak to them everyday and they’re the first I call when I forget how to cook sausages lol. 

My family are pressuring me to spend Christmas with them but things always go wrong and I’m always the one that walks away crying. However when Christmas came around at my foster placement, there were no issues. Everyone was happy. Everyone was relaxed. Whereas things are always tense with my family. Everything has to be perfect. Everyone has to act perfect. And more often than not, I fall out with my sister (10f) and my mother always defends her. Favourite child stuff. I just want a peaceful Christmas, that’s all I want. 

When I told my mother I wanted to spend Christmas with my foster carers she immediately turned cold as she usually is and started guilt tripping me about how the family haven’t spent a single Christmas with Elliot yet. My mother has never liked how Elliot is closer to my foster carers than he is to her and I understand that but I don’t want to take that relationship between Elliot and my foster carers away. 

I talked to my aunt (mothers sister) about this and she told me not to stress about it, spend Christmas with whoever makes you happy. She understands how exhausting and mentally draining family events are. However I’m wondering if I’m in the wrong for choosing to spend Christmas with “people who got paid to look after me” (grandmothers words) instead of my actual family. 
So AITA?

[A little backstory and some more context]
I was placed in foster care at 12 after my abusive dad died. I was grieving for losing a dad but also relieved I was safe. My mother never stepped in to protect me. Grandmother turned a blind eye. I started acting out in my grief, running away, skipping school and having arguments with my mum. She wouldn’t send me to therapy and she couldn’t handle my outbursts so she put me in foster care. 

I got pregnant at 16 so I was moved to my AMAZING foster carers who could better facilitate a mother and child so me and Elliot could stay together. They have continued to support me even after having new placements in and I’ve been gone for 6 months. They’ve bought half the furniture for my house for me with no expectation to being paid back and they’ve always taken Elliot for the odd weekend whenever I’ve gotten a bit overwhelmed or needed a break. 

My Aunt has always been painted as the black sheep and as overdramatic as she has POTS and struggles to get out of bed a lot of days so she’s been very understanding of this and she actually acknowledges and talks to me about how traumatic my childhood was instead of sweeping it under the rug like everyone else in the family.
top_comment_body:
NTA. Your foster fam hasn't been paid in years to look after you. They are a major part of your life because they love you for you. They CHOOSE you. They have no responsibility to you, and yet they have stepped up in ways your bio family never has. 

When you become an adult you realize that you create your own family. Whether that's by having a partner and kids, or finding other people to join together. You have found a family who is not trying to change you, who has been there for you at some of your toughest times and haven't run away. Don't feel guilty for choosing the people who choose you.
gpt_4o_response:
It sounds like you're navigating a challenging situation with a lot of emotional weight. Your desire for a peaceful and happy Christmas is entirely valid, especially considering your past experiences with your family. It's understandable to want to spend the holiday with people who have been supportive and nurturing, like your foster carers, who seem to have played a significant role in your and Elliot's lives. 

Your history suggests that your foster carers have provided the stability and kindness that perhaps were missing in your earlier years. It's natural that you'd want to maintain that positive environment for yourself and your son. Your aunt's advice about spending Christmas with those who make you happy is wise, as your mental well-being is important.

It's not wrong to prioritize your happiness and the well-being of your child. While family expectations can be difficult to manage, choosing a supportive and loving environment for Christmas doesn't make you the bad person. It's about creating a positive and nurturing space for you and Elliot.
claude_response:
Based on your story, you are absolutely not in the wrong here. Your foster carers have demonstrated consistent love, support, and understanding - creating the kind of nurturing environment that you and Elliot deserve, especially during the holidays. They've earned their place as your chosen family through actions, not just biological ties.

Your grandmother's dismissive comment about them being "people who got paid to look after you" reveals a lack of understanding about the deep bonds that can form in foster relationships. These carers have gone above and beyond, supporting you financially and emotionally even after your placement ended.

The contrast between the peaceful Christmases with your foster family versus the tense, performative ones with your biological family is telling. Your mother's guilt-tripping about Elliot, while ignoring her own past failures to protect and support you, shows she's more concerned about appearances than your wellbeing.

Choose the environment that brings you peace and joy. As your aunt wisely said, spend Christmas with those who make you happy. You're making a healthy choice for both yourself and your son.
llama_response:
It sounds like you're caught in a difficult situation, torn between pleasing your family and doing what feels right for you and your son. However, I don't think you're in the wrong for choosing to spend Christmas with your foster carers. They've been a source of love, support, and stability in your life, especially during a time when you needed it most. It's clear that they've become like family to you and Elliot, and it's not about them being paid to care for you, but about the genuine bond you've formed.

It's also understandable that you'd want to avoid the tension and stress that comes with spending Christmas with your biological family. You deserve a peaceful and happy holiday season, and if that means spending it with people who make you feel loved and supported, then that's what you should do. Don't let guilt trips or criticism from your family make you feel otherwise. You're doing what's best for you and your son, and that's something to be proud of.
gpt_oss_response: It sounds like you’re navigating a very painful history while trying to create a safe, joyful holiday for yourself and Elliot. The foster carers have been a constant, loving presence for both of you, and the stress and judgment you feel from your grandmother’s “perfect picture” suggest that Christmas with family is a source of anxiety rather than comfort. Your mother’s guilt‑tripping, while hurtful, comes from a place of fear about losing a connection with her grandson, but that fear doesn’t override Elliot’s need for stability. AITA? No. You’re prioritizing your child’s emotional well‑being and your own mental health over a tradition that feels harmful. If you can, let your mother know the specific ways her expectations hurt you and ask for a compromise—perhaps a visit after the holidays. Until then, spending Christmas with the people who truly support you is a legitimate choice.

title: AITAH for letting my kid see my ex despite being in a new relationship
body:
I’m on a throwaway bc my man is on Reddit and there’s a lot of specific info here lmao. 

I’m 23F. I have a 4-year-old son, and for the past 6 months I’ve been seeing a man who I will call Chris (38M). About a year ago, I broke up with Matt (26M). I left my son’s father on very bad terms when I was pregnant, and was single for the next couple years while I got my proverbial shit in a pile. Matt was the first guy I ever dated since breaking up with my son’s father, and we went out for a little under a year and a half. While we dated, he forged a very close bond with my son, and they still spend time together. We broke up for good, though, because he got a girl in his masters program pregnant. This was devastating to me, but because he had a wonderful relationship with my son,  I didn’t want my son’s relationship with his only real father figure to just end overnight, so he still spends some time with Matt. I want to be an adult about this situation.  Matt wants my son to pop by this weekend so he can give him his Christmas present. 

Enter Chris. Chris has been dating me for 6 months now and I’m thinking about introducing him to my son, as I have a “6 month minimum.” Chris wanted to do it this weekend and, in a conversation about scheduling, I mentioned that my son would briefly stop by at my ex’s to get his present and see the baby. Chris was offended by this, because he said it indicated I was still emotionally enmeshed with my ex (I am not really on great terms with Matt right now, but try to put that aside). He said this was disrespectful to him and would teach my son “horrible lessons about women.” 

I’m trying to do the best job I can with everything.  AITAH?
top_comment_body:
NTA 

Chris is controlling (unsurprising given the age difference), he’s chosen to date you knowing you already have a kid and that the kid has a father. If he tries to shame you or get in the way then he’s not the one sis.

Your decision to let your son see Matt seems to come from a place of wanting to keep a stable father figure presence for him, which is commendable.

It might help to have an open conversation with Chris to explain your intentions and reassure him about your commitment to your relationship. It's important to communicate that your decision is about your son's welfare and not about lingering feelings for Matt.

Balancing new relationships while co-parenting is challenging, but as long as your decisions center on what's best for your son, you're striving to be a thoughtful and caring parent.

title: AITAH for not wanting my step parents I’m my life?
body:
Context needed but I 21M have had stepparents I’m my life since my actual parents divorced when I was 13. I was always told that they wouldn’t be interrupting my life during school and college, however that was a huge lie. Since they always said how I should do X,Y and Z or how I should and shouldn’t date a person they’ve never met because they had a partly shady past. Recently I’ve been dating my girlfriend who we’ll call A 21F. They’ve been saying when’s the wedding, when are we getting married, when are we going to see her etc etc. We’ve been dating 3 months and I know how much it’s affecting her putting pressure on her to make an appearance. Last week my parents were together at my younger sisters 19th birthday party, they wanted to know my A wasn’t here I politely said to both my step-mum and stepdad that A was working ( she works as a nurse at the city hospital). I don’t know what came over them but they demanded that I gave a better excuse and I was lying. I said that I wasn’t lying and that they are ruining my sisters day. They went on a rampage telling anyone who would listen that I was a compulsive liar and how I’ve ruined there lives. I snapped. I told them F Off and said how I was done with them and never wanted them in my life again, I then left the party. Since last week both my parents have tried calling and texting me on how I should give both my stepparents another chance. I have said no and stopped answering there text and calls. I feel bad for what I said I’m usually level headed but that tipped me over the edge should I give them another chance after giving them a million others. AITAH

Edit: a couple of people have noticed about the time length of my girlfriend relating to a post of which I asked for some advice a while ago. Well done those who realised and twigged on. Honestly I forgot about that post entirely and thought most of Reddit had. But I would like to mention me and my GF have been on and off for 7 months we had some issues at the start. I should have put that but in but I totally forgot about it until a couple of mentions on this post about it. Sorry for the miss communication all
top_comment_body:
NTA and you have every right to block them from your life. I would tell your bio parents that the only way they can see you from now on is without their obnoxious, overbearing spouses. Said obnoxious, overbearing spouses are not viewed as family. If bio parents want any involvement in your life going forward, including wedding and future grandchildren, they will learn to respect your boundaries. And, while you should not have to state it, their obnoxious, overbearing spouses will never have any role in the lives of any future family if you have one.

They stomp over you boundaries at their own peril.
op_engaged_comment_body: NTA, but I'm curious is this the same girl with kidney problems?? if it isn't maybe they think u 2 have been dating for almost a year and that's why they push so hard. still doesn't make u the AH but it does explain it
gpt_4o_response:
It sounds like you're going through a really challenging situation with your stepparents. It's understandable to feel overwhelmed when people who are supposed to be supportive become a source of stress. Your feelings of frustration and wanting to set boundaries are valid, especially when you feel like your personal life is being scrutinized and pressured unnecessarily.

From what you've shared, it seems like you're trying to balance being respectful while also protecting your own and your girlfriend's boundaries. It's clear that you care about your family, but it's also important to take care of your own well-being and mental health. You might want to consider having a calm conversation with your parents about how their actions affect you, if and when you feel ready. This could help them understand your perspective and possibly lead to a healthier relationship moving forward.

Ultimately, whether or not you decide to give your stepparents another chance is entirely up to you. Trust your instincts and prioritize your peace of mind. Remember, it's okay to set boundaries and take a step back if that's what you need right now.
claude_response:

It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of boundary violations and pressure from your stepparents, which has built up over years. Your frustration is completely understandable. At 21, you have the right to manage your relationships and personal life without constant interference or accusations.

The fact that they publicly accused you of lying about your girlfriend's work schedule and tried to create drama at your sister's birthday party shows a concerning pattern of controlling behavior and disrespect for your boundaries. Your reaction, while heated, came after multiple attempts to handle things politely.

You're not the asshole for wanting space from people who repeatedly disregard your boundaries and create unnecessary conflict. While it's admirable that your parents want peace, they need to understand that reconciliation requires your stepparents to show genuine respect for your autonomy and boundaries.

Consider communicating clearly (perhaps in writing) what boundaries you need them to respect if they want to be part of your life. But don't feel guilty about protecting your peace and mental well-being.

On the other hand, you're frustrated with their constant meddling and pressure, especially when it affects your relationship with your girlfriend. 

It seems like you've been carrying this burden for a long time, and their behavior at your sister's birthday party was the final straw. You're not just reacting to the current situation, but also to all the past instances where they've overstepped boundaries. 

It's understandable that you don't want to give them another chance, considering they've been given many chances before and yet, their behavior hasn't changed. It's essential to prioritize your own emotional well-being and set boundaries to protect yourself and your relationship. 

While it's natural to feel bad about what you said, it's also crucial to acknowledge that your stepparents' actions have consequences. Perhaps it's time to re-evaluate your relationship with them and consider what's best for you and your future.

title: AITAH For telling my mother my brother couldn’t move into my grans house so she should stop telling him he can
body:
I (21M) have lived with my grandparents since I was born. Nothing happened between my mother and I that I couldn’t stay with her I just never settled into her house when she moved out as I had spent the first 2 years of my life constantly spending time with my gran while my mother was at work.

My mother has more children but the main two are my brothers Jay (19M) and Harry (17M).

As I got older my gran informed me that my aunt and mother argued that when my uncle moved out either my cousin or Jay would move in. My cousin who is 15 used to be a bit of a trouble maker but has since calmed down. Whereas my brother has constantly been a trouble maker, he constantly starts arguments with Harry and myself, breaks his things and our things, talks back to our mother and since he’s moved in with his girlfriend every argument they get into they involve my mother and causes her stress.

Jay has lived with his girlfriend for a couple of months, he moved in with her around the same time our uncle finally moved out of my grans house.

When my uncle moved out my gran told me that her and my grandfather agreed I could have his room while keeping my room to turn one of the rooms into a mini living room as my bedroom was very small and cramped anytime I had friends over. Since then I’ve spent a lot of my own money decorating the room, I moved in my tv and bought myself a couch so that whenever I had friends over we had somewhere to sit.

Which brings me to the issue. A few weeks back my mother told my gran about how she told Jay that if him and his girlfriend break up he has to find his own apartment as the house has been a lot calmer since he moved out and that anytime he comes to visit he constantly starts arguments with Harry. She then told my gran that she told Jay that since she has the spare room he could just move in with us.

My gran explained that all my stuff was in the spare room and that we didn’t have a second bed. She told my mother that he could stay a night or two if he had to but she wasn’t having him stay constantly.

A few weeks later my mother mentions it again, she asked my gran why Jay can’t sleep on my sofa bed (I don’t own one) and when my gran explained this she asked why he couldn’t just sleep on the couch or why can’t I sleep on the couch and he can have my bed as I don’t need two rooms.

My gran explained that my couch wasn’t the biggest and that I paid for it myself so if Jay was to move in he wouldn’t have anything in the room as all my stuff would be moved into the one room.

A few days later my mother then asks me if I’d be willing to let Jay have my extra room and to leave my tv and couch in the room so he’s able to play his Xbox and have somewhere to sleep. I told her no as I paid for my tv and couch myself and I wasn’t going to inconvenience myself because she was refusing to let Jay move in. At this my mother called me selfish for not being willing to share with my brother and that with work and university I wouldn’t be using my tv and PlayStation as much so he should be allowed to have the spare room and use my things.

When I got home I told my gran all this. I asked if she told my mother he could move in to which she said no as she couldn’t handle or afford to keep him as my mother had him expecting to have everything replaced if he breaks it and doesn’t want to deal with his rudeness. She told me she repeatedly told my mother he wasn’t moving in which she is ignoring.

After this I texted my mother saying that my gran has already told her Jay isn’t moving in and that even if he was I wouldn’t give him my tv and stuff. She once again called me selfish and told me I didn’t deserve my stuff if I wasn’t willing to share with my brother.

I feel like an asshole but know he’d break my things and know my gran doesn’t want to deal with his attitude. So AITAH?
top_comment_body:
NTA

This isn't just about protecting your belongings; it's also about protecting your grandmother's well being. Stand firm.
op_engaged_comment_body: NTA at all. Jay needs to understand that his shitty actions have consequences; so does your mom. Stand firm, and block Jay and your mom temporarily, if you need to. Your grandmother doesn't need that kind of stress, and your mom knows that, she's just hoping that she can trick you and your grandma into letting Jay stay there so she doesn't have to be bothered. The nonchalant way in which she expected you to just leave your expensive electronics available to be broken by your brother with the anger issues is telling. Protect your peace and let Jay get a job and find somewhere else to live.

You’ve communicated your stance clearly, and it seems like you’re trying to maintain peace by setting boundaries, which is important for your well-being.

It's not selfish to want to keep your space and belongings intact, especially if you've invested your own resources into them. Perhaps further open communication with your mother could help, emphasizing the reasons behind your decision, and reinforcing the fact that it's a collective family decision. You’re not the asshole for wanting to maintain your living space and the peace within your home.

Stay firm but kind in maintaining these boundaries. Your mother's frustration doesn't make you selfish or wrong.

title: AITAH for asking my ex to rent an apartment with a room for our daughter?
body:
We are newly separated, he is moving out soon. I hope!! All he is looking for are 1 bedroom apartment all included (appliances, sofa, tables etc.). Easy solution, thats true. That means he leaves me everything. Absolutely nothing fancy, old stuff we accumulated over the years. He gets to go in a new apt with everything brand new. Yes, i am feeling a bit jealous... 
BUT. My real problem is he is not providing our daughter with a room of her own. To me this a real basic, pragmatic thing to have. No? He says he never tought of that, that i am now throwing him a curveball, that he will never find such a thing, too expensive  yadiyadiyada.
True, the market is expensive. But it is for him and me, equally. 
We had a big fight about it. He blames me for everything. It was my decision to end our relationship, but i naively tought we could work it out like normal people do: ie share custody and coparent. 
But, he said that no, our daughter will be with me most of the time. Si i guess we will not be sharing custody after all. Not that i mind, i much prefer to have my daughter with me, its great. But I find it sad for her. 
Should i continue to insist he finds an apartment with 2 bedrooms? AITAH for asking for it? Should i let go?

EDIT. Thank all of you for your answers, keeping my ego in check and being concerned about my daughter well being. All your answers have given me a good spectrum on viewpoints and helped me tremendously. 
My ex and i have talked, and we came to an agreement. And, our daughter is happy and excited about his new place. The 1 bdr apt. 
Thanks, have a blessed day!
top_comment_body: NTA...you were right to point that out to him. He gave his response. Now you know you get to keep your daughter.  Don't push him to get a 2 bedroom. Accept that he didn't envision his child in his life for probably more than a few hours a week. She's old enough to understand that, but you don't have to tell her that. Let him explain why he doesn't have room for her at HIS home. Her home is with you. Its so sad for her and I hope you do your best to be there for her and be sympathetic and understanding of any behaviors that follow this split. Get her therapy if she needs it to process all this. You'll be going through a lot yourself, but she is innocent in all this and has no say in the decisions her parents make that directly affect her. She has no control, so she may try to control other things in her life that may cause frustration for you. Just be aware of that and be there for her because it sounds like he is only interested in parenting on occasion for a few hours or maybe an over night one or two weekends a month.
op_engaged_comment_body:
YTA- You broke up with him and are pretty much telling him what to do in his home. You lost that right when the relationship ended. If your daughter is small than she doesn’t need a room. Let him get himself together since he’s leaving everything to you. I assume you are also going to want money for your daughter. You are unrealistic. Let him get himself together and help you financially before he worries about another room.

The courts are going to tell you the same thing.

title: AITAH for expecting my parents to help me out financially through post secondary education?
body:
I (21F) got in a huge argument with my (41M) step-dad last week over finances regarding my education and living situation. I apologize in advance if i'm giving too many details but I think they are important for the full story. 

For some context I'm the eldest of 5 children (3 from my moms side) 13F half-sis mom shared, 19F full sis, (2 from step-dad) 15M step-sibling and 19F step-sibling. My half-sis (13F) is with her dad 50% of the time, my full sis and I's father stopped paying child support when I was 10 and is out of the picture due to alcoholism, and my step siblings mother passed away in 2011. My mother and step father got together in 2013 and we re-located to the city my step father already lived in that same year to all live together.

We all apart from my 13F half-sis lived with our parents full time up until last year when my (19F step-sis) moved out with her bf into one of those portable trailers that attach to the back of a truck bed parked on her grandfathers property (my step grandpa). She moved out due to conflict with my parents. She is attending uni next semester through student loans at a local college. 

My step-dad makes around 175k a year managing his fathers company with him, and my mother although holds a diploma in nursing (LPN in Canada) has not worked for the last year and a half.

Now that the backstory is in place I can get into it. My parents are currently not speaking to me over an argument I had a week ago with my step-father. It started out as my brother getting a form signed to go into full-time IB for his grade 11 and 12 year. I asked why he was doing IB, my parents explained it was because he gets his first year off of uni credits. This is only true if he is going into a general degree and a couple weeks ago he was telling everyone he wanted to go into Architecture (IB will not count), I think it's a bad idea, his credits will not count towards the degree he wants to go in and he has awful study habits, I don't think he understands the amount of effort he will have to put into IB, none of the less, not my problem, but this is how the conversation started. 

I asked how he is going to afford to go to university as I have been having an extremely hard time affording it myself and my parents said "what do you mean of course we will help him, all of you kids are going to go to university". I responded with "you have not helped me I have had to delay my studies in order to afford it myself". This turned into an argument where both me and my step father were raising our voices, and me crying while my mother did not say much. She chimed in saying I transferred money to her a couple times but my step dad didn't really listen. My step-father was insisting he payed 6K towards my school, then brought the number down to 3K, when in reality it has been $0-500 he has contributed. Where this gets confusing is we have been using his account to pay my tuition and I have transferred my mother the money as my college does not accept transfers through my specific bank. My dads money is my moms money, she does not work but they have both joint and separate accounts. All in all for 30 credits of my BSN & a 6 month certificate program I took has cost $8400. $3196 I have proof I transferred (my bank only lets me go back a year), 1.9K from my moms parents I have proof of, and 1.5K my bio dads mom gave me. 1800$ is unaccounted for as I can't go that far back in my banking, there is no record. He had his finger pointed in my face calling me a brat, spoiled and selfish for reacting harshly for calling him out on his lie. He has not contributed to my school, for him to be remotely right that would mean I paid for nothing of my 30 credits when I did, I transferred my mother money, we don't know the exact amount. I can remember 1 semester he MAYBE topped off around $500 and that is being generous. 

Due to his income I cannot get student loans, I have applied, they sent a letter back saying I qualified for 0$. The average cost of a 1 bedroom basement suit where I live is $1600 a month. It is next to impossible to afford rent as a student. In order to be classified as an independent student not attached to my parents income I have to be 4 years post graduated HS, or live on my own for 1 whole year. MAX student loan is 1.5k per month. For my major (nursing) I have to have a vehicle, it is noted in the entrance requirements as some clinical placements are 1-2 hr drive away from the school, 12hr shifts with no transiting options. So this is another expense. I live 1.5-2hr commute to any uni/ college, 3-4hr both ways. I pay 100% of my car expenses $500 fixed (250 insurance lowest possible for my age I know crazy here in British Columbia, 250 paying my parents back as they paid upfront) + gas. 10k tuition a year when I continue. I went to school Monday-Friday and worked Saturday & Sundays. No days off for months. The only thing my parents help out with is not charging me rent or food (I'm small I eat maybe $200 worth of groceries a month), their rent would not go down if I moved out, they would probably use my room as storage. I plan on moving out for the other 3 years of my BSN with my bf but without saving 1.5k/month for the next year I wont be able to afford it, even with max student loans. AITA for expecting them to contribute to my education when they said they will be helping my brother? AITA for calling him out on his lie? I have delayed my education for so long as I can't get loans. I have been the only child in university for the last 3 years.

Edit: Thanks for all the comments I didn’t expect this post to blow up as much as it did or be so controversial. I appreciate the different insights & came to Reddit for somewhat unbiased opinions.
top_comment_body: NTA I think the point many are missing is that he claims to be helping her when he very much isn’t
op_engaged_comment_body:
Also, she had a choice. She could've delay her studies for a year, get a job, live on her own and she would've been eligible for a loans.

But she wants to live home, not pay rent and foodm and still get money.

title: AITA for telling an old lady to not touch my baby??
body:
I know it sounds weird… but let me elaborate:
I had a baby in april. My husband and I went out to a Park, just to catch some walk and sun, and be out. 
I was sitting in a bench, holding my child in my chest, with his head on my shoulder when a unknown lady comes from behind saying: “what a beautiful baby” and extending her hand out to touch his face/head. I almost saw everything in slow Motion. I told her to please not touch him. The lady was really offended and replied that she loves babies and no one ever told her no. I repeated that she cannot touch him, since I dont know her. She left fuming and saying I was crazy. My husband actually told me that Im being an AH for telling her no, instead of just obliging. 

I feel I was right. But… AITA?

Edit: thank you all for your kind comments. Its very hard as a mom to know when you go “momcrazy” or being rational. Thanks

NTA 

I don’t understand why people think babies and pregnant people become public property.  She could have germs on her dirty hands which coupd make your baby sick.  Good for you for standing up to an entitled witch.  You did the right thing.

Hell, even if it was someone you know — that is your choice! She can get over it. What if she had a cold sore or any virus on her hands?? That’s something that could be with your child forever

title: AITAH For breaking up with my gf for being polyamory?
body: I 21 male and she 20 female, had been going out for a few weeks. She told me she is polyamory. ( for those who don’t know, it’s being in a relationship with multiple partners.) I have been thinking about this for a few days now, and broke up with her bc I don’t want her to change who she is for me. And if we stayed together, I will be competing for her affection, and I shouldn’t be doing that in a relationship. When I broke things off she told me I was an asshole. When I told my friend about, he said he understood my point of view but still called me the asshole. So am I the asshole?

title: AITAH for not forgetting my partner's cheating history?
body: I, 31 F, am living with my partner 34 M in a one bedroom apartment. I caught him multiple times cheating with different girls. I have no idea whether or not they replied to him or even met him in person.  He always DM them things that almost in the border of him feeling lust towards their pictures. I tried to forgive him but everytime I ask where he is, he gets angry and say mean things to me. To get even, I always bring up that I won't have trust issues if he had been loyal in the first place then recalling all his past chats. Am I being unfair saying that I forgive him even if I never forgot all these things he did? I admit, when I am alone the screenshots of the DMs he sent still eat me alive.
top_comment_body: YTA to yourself. He’s showed you “multiple times” that he doesn’t respect you, and so far you’ve refused to believe him. Have some respect for yourself and leave.
op_engaged_comment_body:
NTA. Apology without a changed behavior is manipulation. It is his fault that he has cheated. If you decided to forgive him, he should be grateful you’re still with him. Now the forgetting part is difficult. Since it was his fault for cheating, he needs to go out of his way to give you reassurance. For example, turn his location on, call you, take you with him when he’s out etc. Only by reassurance, over time that trust can be somewhat restored.

Also, the other comments are saying that you are not sure if he cheated or if he was just DMing girls. To be honest, DMing girls is not “nothing”. Don’t invalidate OP’s feelings. It’s pretty embarrassing for a woman when your 34 year old partner acts like a high school kid and gives everyone attention.

It sounds like you're caught in a really difficult and painful situation. Trust is fundamental in a relationship, and when it's broken, it can be incredibly hard to rebuild. It's understandable that you're struggling to forget what happened, especially if his actions continue to hurt you. Your feelings of betrayal and the impact on your ability to trust are valid. It seems like you're trying to navigate between wanting to forgive and protect yourself from further hurt.

However, it might be helpful to examine whether holding onto these past events is serving you or your relationship. Forgiveness doesn’t necessarily mean forgetting, but it does mean finding a way to move forward, whether together or apart. Open and honest communication with your partner about how his actions have affected you might be necessary. You both deserve to feel secure and respected in the relationship, and if that's not possible, it may be worth considering whether this relationship is meeting your emotional needs. Seeking support from a counselor or therapist could also offer guidance as you work through these complex emotions.
claude_response:
You're not being unfair at all. Trust, once broken, takes significant time and genuine effort from both parties to rebuild. From what you've described, your partner isn't showing remorse or making efforts to rebuild trust - instead, he's becoming defensive and hostile when you seek basic reassurance about his whereabouts.

The fact that the screenshots still haunt you and he continues to react with anger rather than understanding suggests that true healing hasn't occurred in your relationship. Forgiveness doesn't mean forgetting or pretending the hurt never happened. It seems like you're carrying the emotional burden of his infidelity while he's avoiding accountability.

Consider whether this dynamic is healthy for you. A partner who truly wants to rebuild trust after cheating should be patient, transparent, and understanding of your need for reassurance - not responding with anger and mean comments. You deserve a relationship where you feel secure and respected, not one where you're constantly wrestling with trust issues while your partner dismisses your valid concerns.

title: AITAH for telling my best friends girlfriend to grow up and allegedly ruining his relationship
body:
I (21f) and my best friend (21m) we will call him “B”, had been best friends since we were born, growing up right across the street from each other. When I say best friends, we literally talked (if we weren’t hanging out) until this incident all day everyday. 

Last February (2021) B met a girl where he lives named E (19f) and they began dating, B moved 3 hours away after high school but we still saw each other frequently. He wanted me to meet her, so he brought her to our hometown to hangout. Her and I got along so good, and for about 2 months we all remained close, I considered her one of my best friends. 

Her and B had an argument, B reached out to me via text to vent. I do not like to be involved in any way, but he is my best friend and it is my job to be a shoulder to lean on. He didn’t say much, and in my responses to him I sort of defended E as this situation I understood her side more. There was maybe 6 exchanged texts totals and they were fine not even 20 min later. Or so I thought…

Fast forward to Easter, E goes through his phone and looks at our texts. I had not known this until asking why she began to ghost me for a week. She broke up with B and blamed him venting to me as “being a part of their relationship” even though B is the one who came to me, and told B she felt as if he listened to my advice more serious than hers. So as you readers can already see where this is going, it was a “her or me” type deal from E. She told B she would not give him another chance until I talked to her and apologized  for “being a part of their relationship.” B begged that I do this for him despite him admittedly knowing she was in the wrong. I did it only because I knew how much it meant to him, not that I felt like I did anything wrong. She never responded, she didn’t get back with him like she said, she instead tormented him and emotionally abused him said extremely disgusting things about me. B even caught her back with her (said to be abusive)  ex. At this point, B was in pain so I sent an additional text telling her to grow up. This made things harder for B as she immediately blocked his # and he decided to blame loosing her on me, in which I sent a final text to him as well telling him how I feel about him throwing me into this situation and how hurt I was. He never responded and it has been 7 months since we have spoken. 

I thought I did everything I could for him despite the situation he dragged me into and how badly E treated me, and how he let her do so. AITA for sending her that final text and causing this? I am so hurt that I feel I should have let them continue to treat me poorly so I didn’t lose his friendship permanently. I feel I am grieving the loss of someone who is still alive. 

Disclaimer: I have my own bf (23) of 8 years, this is NOT a situation where the girl best friend  deep down wants the guy.
top_comment_body: You are NTA. He put you in the middle of the situation, you reacted like any friend would, and it sounds like they had a toxic relationship. You probably shouldn’t have sent that text, mostly because there was no point to it at that point in their relationship. Your friend and his ex girlfriend are the assholes here.
op_engaged_comment_body: You were LITERALLY attached at the hip? Was the operation painful?
gpt_4o_response:

You were put in a difficult position, where you were trying to support your best friend, B, and maintain a friendship with E. It seems like your intentions were to help and not to interfere negatively in their relationship.

It's important to remember that friendships and relationships can be very complex, and sometimes people react in ways that are unexpected. It seems like E's reaction and B's subsequent blame were beyond your control. You were honest with B about your feelings, which shows that you value authenticity and transparency.

You might consider reaching out to B again, expressing that you miss his friendship and are open to a conversation if he's willing. Sometimes, time can bring clarity and healing. Regardless of the outcome, remember that you deserve to be treated with respect, and it's okay to set boundaries when you feel mistreated.

Ultimately, you're not responsible for how others choose to handle their emotions, and it's okay to prioritize your well-being.
claude_response:
Based on the dialog example and situation described, here's my response:

You're not the asshole here. It seems you're carrying a lot of guilt over a situation that wasn't your fault. You acted as any good friend would - being supportive when B needed to vent, even trying to see E's perspective, and ultimately standing up for yourself when things became toxic.

E's behavior shows clear signs of controlling and manipulative tactics - going through B's phone, creating ultimatums, and using emotional abuse. While it hurts deeply to lose such a long-term friendship, B made his choice to enable this toxic behavior rather than recognize the unfair position you were put in.

It's natural to second-guess yourself and wonder if you should have just accepted the poor treatment to keep the peace. But maintaining healthy boundaries, even when painful, doesn't make you the bad person. You're grieving the loss of an important friendship, and that's completely valid. Sometimes standing up for ourselves costs us relationships, but that doesn't mean we were wrong to do so.

On the other hand, you're left wondering if you should have just let things go to avoid losing B's friendship. It seems like you were put in a very difficult position - being asked to apologize for something you didn't feel was your fault, and then being blamed for the consequences of your actions.

It's understandable that you would want to tell E to "grow up" after the way she treated you and B, especially given her history of emotional abuse. It's not like you went out of your way to sabotage their relationship; B came to you for support and you were trying to be a good friend. It's also worth noting that E's behavior was toxic and controlling, and B's willingness to blame you for their breakup is concerning.

title: AITA for breaking up with my boyfriend because he was late to our one year anniversary?
body:
I (F18) and my boyfriend Liam (M19) were supposed to go on a date for our one year anniversary. It was 9:00 in the morning and our date was in an hour meaning I didn’t get much time to get ready as I wanted to make the date super special. I wore a dress he bought me when we were just 5 months and shoes I bought 3 days before the anniversary. I straightened my hair and styled it and all of that caused me to have 20 minutes left until the date started. Liam had texted me saying he’s gonna be 15 minutes late and I assumed that was because he was making a special surprise for us so I just responded with a quick “ok!” I had went to the restaurant 10 minutes early and waited for about 30 minutes, when I had texted him asking when he was coming he told me that he couldn’t go because his dad needed him for something important and he lives about 20 minutes away from him. I asked why it was so important and he didn’t respond. It’s been nearly 10 minutes. 

I texted him saying, “Liam, I have prepared a lot for our one year anniversary. I thought this was something special for us, what is so important that you have to miss it?” He read it and rudely asked if it was a prank as I always joke around with him. I was so disappointed. He texted me telling me that he had forgotten and thought we were going on a regular date. I was so upset and tears were about to come out of my eyes. I waited a while to see if he would respond and apologize and to also calm myself down. I had left the restaurant and walked to my car as I didn’t get a response but right when I open my car door I see his car parking. When he had left the car, his appearance had seemed to have no effort. He quickly ran to me and apologized.

I told him to give me a couple days and that I didn’t wanna talk to him at the moment. I went in my car and was on my way home. I quickly noticed that his car was following mine and when I got home I opened the door and went inside locking it quickly. I get a text shortly after of Liam telling me to open the door so that we could talk about it. I ignored the text for nearly 20 minutes and prepared some food, I couldn’t get my mind off of it so I shortly left the food I was preparing on the counter and unlocked the door. To my surprise he had already left. I started to cry.

I sent him paragraphs of how I had prepared so much for our anniversary and he just shows up effortlessly dressed and had just left without understanding that I needed some time until I wanted to talk to you and just left. He told me that he was genuinely sorry and that he had left because I made him wait outside for nearly 20 minutes without hearing his explanation. I called him asking for his explanation and I heard his dad saying “So have you told her yet?” I asked Liam what his dad was talking about but he shortly ended the call and I knew it was something serious that he’s been keeping from me and I didn’t want to get more hurt mentally when I find out what it is so I chose to tell him that I wanted to break up to make things less complicated.
top_comment_body:
Yeah. You kinda suck here. But I’m assuming it’s cause you’re still very young. 

1. You can’t expect your secret efforts to be as important to him as they are to you. 

2. You were aware something happened with his father and still only focused on you. You could have actually listened to him. Sure leave the restaurant but be an adult and have a conversation. 

3. You literally expected him to stand outside begging for you like some dumbass romance? That’s not how real life works. 

4. You didn’t break up to make things less complicated. You broke up with him because his perception of the day and his priorities didn’t immediately align with what you wanted. And you’re likely hoping he comes chasing after you. 

Work on yourself. All of this is self-centered and immature.

YTAH

Edits: words

It’s clear that this date meant a lot to you, and it’s valid to feel upset when expectations aren't met, especially on such a significant day. Communication and understanding are key in any relationship, and it seems like there was a breakdown in both areas between you and Liam.

It's important to prioritize your own feelings and mental well-being. If you felt that breaking up was the best decision to protect yourself from further emotional pain, then that’s a valid choice. title: AITA who apparently ruined thanksgiving?

Couple backed out bc all of the following:
1. They don’t know my dad like that and don’t know what “intricate” reasoning there might be for him to come over. 
2. This changes the couples vibe bc they thought it was going to be just us and now my dad changes things. 
3. Some other scheduling stuff that would have had them leave a day earlier. 

I’m offended because what intricate detail is there for my dad to come stay with us and babysit, which he’s done before?

title: AITAH for not wanting to be involved with my In Laws now?
body:
When our kids were 1 & 3 yrs, we undertook major house renovations as Owner-Builders including removing the roof, adding another storey, staircase etc and re-roofing the house. 

My husband did a lot of the coordination and physical work, while I (32F) still worked, looked after kids, ran the household (cooking, pets etc), handled finances and building admin like getting quotes. 

My husband had a serious accident with several significant internal injuries. Big operation, was in hospital for 10 days, and then literally laid on the couch extremely unwell for 4 mths (he had several follow up surgeries in that time). 

It was unclear at the time whether he would fully recover or have life-long problems. 

At the time of his accident, we had no roof on the house, and it was summer/Christmas shut down here in Australia. I needed to get some painting and other tasks done before the roof went on in early January. 
With no tradespeople available, I begged all our friends, my-in-laws and all our acquaintances for help so I could juggle it all. 
(I have no family in Australia). 

My in laws opted not to help: not an hour of child minding, not a meal dropped off, no help with the renovation project. They decided that I was wildly exaggerating and they were busy with their own lives. 
...anyway, with the help of friends, I got the prep done, roof went onto the house. Kids somehow had food and clean clothes each day and even wrapped Christmas gifts. I even managed to visit my husband in hospital briefly to make him feel settled. 

Now, I don't feel like hanging out with my in laws. They weren't there for me when I truly needed them. They just made zero effort for me, they didn't even call or text to check in.

My husband says they aren't great but are the only family he has, it's a while ago now and I should suck it up. 

He is welcome to see them, but when I can, I prefer to not go along. 

AITAH?
top_comment_body: NTA and I don’t understand why your husband would want to see them. But I agree with you, that’s up to him but I wouldn’t visit and not sure I would even want my kids seeing them.
op_engaged_comment_body: NTA and I don’t understand why your husband would want to see them. But I agree with you, that’s up to him but I wouldn’t visit and not sure I would even want my kids seeing them.
gpt_4o_response:
It sounds like you went through an incredibly challenging time, juggling multiple responsibilities under immense pressure. It's understandable that you feel hurt and disappointed by your in-laws' lack of support during such a critical period. It seems you did everything possible to keep things together, and having no help from them when you needed it most must have been difficult.

Your feelings are valid, and it's important to acknowledge that. It's natural to want to distance yourself from those who weren't there for you in a time of crisis. However, maintaining a relationship with your in-laws for the sake of family dynamics, especially considering your husband's perspective, might be worth considering in the long run.

Perhaps having an open conversation with your husband about your feelings could help both of you find a balance that respects your emotional needs while also considering his family ties. It might also be beneficial to set boundaries that allow you to protect your well-being while navigating familial relationships.
claude_response:
Based on your experience, you are not the asshole for wanting to distance yourself from your in-laws. Their complete lack of support during a genuine family crisis - when your husband was seriously injured, you had no roof over your head, and two young children to care for - reveals a concerning lack of empathy and family commitment.

While your husband's perspective about them being his only family is understandable, you're not preventing him from maintaining his relationship with them. You're simply choosing to limit your own interaction based on their past behavior, which is a reasonable boundary to set.

Their decision to dismiss your situation as "wildly exaggerating" rather than offering even minimal support (like a meal or quick check-in) demonstrates poor judgment and a concerning lack of care for their own son's family in crisis.

It's healthy to acknowledge these feelings rather than "sucking it up." Consider maintaining polite but limited contact for major family events while supporting your husband's choice to have his own relationship with them.
llama_response:
It sounds like you felt deeply hurt and abandoned by your in-laws during a critical moment in your life. It's understandable that their lack of support, especially when you reached out for help, has left a lasting impression on you.

It's not about 'sucking it up' or pretending like everything is okay when it's not. Your feelings are valid, and you have every right to set boundaries that make you feel comfortable. title: I understand that this is a 1st world problem and I sound Spolied AF... buuuttttt
body:

I did... damn was it hard with a new born and just recently being abandoned by deadbeat.

Well FFS they drove my little car (that even I don't drive like this) 2000 miles in ONE F@CKEN WEEK!!!

Now I'm stuck with the up keep, had to get an oil change as my car was basically left with NO OIL, half a tank, and bald tired like did y'all go to drifting events!?!

title: AITA for telling my bf I’m not gonna financially support him if he just gives it to his parents?

During that time his mom and dad stalked me on social media and said I was a whore, cheater, and liar for having a new bf at the time. When we did get back together him and I found out I was pregnant. So we decided to move in together. (His parents said I should get an abortion and leave his life). Just some back story, I’ve been on my own since i was 18 and he’s lived with his parents his whole life. Since living together his parents expect him to still pay bills at there house, let them use his truck and not put gas, and take up a lot of his time. I told him that none of these things he has to do but he told me to be more “understanding and don’t judge”. Things he didn’t say when I was being called nasty names by them. So I said if he wanted to help then he could but I wouldn’t be paying any bills he’s short on (his truck payments and braces) if he wanted to just use the money for them. He’s now calling me controlling and unreasonable because I don’t want to pay for his family. I really need another opinion. So tell me AITA?

title: Aita for not wanting to give up my first class seat to sit with my bf.

title: AITAH for refusing to research open realtionships
body:
Throwaway for obvious reasons. 

I (m29) and my Fiancee (f29) have been together for 5 years overall, engaged for 2. I have always thought we were compatible but recently that has not been the case. 

My Fiancee, started a new job just over a year ago and I was ecstatic for her. She loves her job and has made alot of new friends who are generally cool people. One of these friends I will call, Becca she has got extremely close to and considers her best friend.

Last week we were having a few quiet drinks after date night and my Fiancee began talking about Becca and how her and her husband are ina open marriage. I kind of suspected this is the case from the times we have hung out with them and I don't judge them for it, they seem happy. I do know however this is something that i wouldnt want, and i was clear about this at the start of our relationship.

My Fiancee then admitted she had been talking to Becca about it and states she has been thinking about it over the last few weeks and she would be curious to hear more about it and wanted me to do some research with her. I was quite taken back and reminded her of my stance on open relationships, that we have discussed previously. This started a small argument of which she said that people can change their views over time and was upset that I refused to look into it with her. She called me narrow-minded and said it is better to be educated about such things, even if we don't end up doing it. I declined to look intp it and she ended up going to bed after this and ever since she the atmosphere has been cold and she has been distant. 

I love her very much and don't want to lose her but I know that I wouldnt be able to have an open relationship or invite someone else to bed with us. 

I'm not sure if there is any type of compromise or not, and not really sure if our relationship is over now? AITAH for not researching it with her?
top_comment_body: NTA - I have many poly friends. My husband and are monogamous. Next time she brings it up. “I need to be very clear with you about my boundaries here. I’m not going to stop you researching or gaining knowledge on anything. But I am not and never will be ok with an open relationship. If that isn’t going to work for you then we need to end this relationship. If you keep pressuring me to open it, I will end the relationship. Are we clear on this?”
gpt_4o_response:
It sounds like you're in a challenging situation, and it’s clear that you love your fiancée and value your relationship. It’s important to recognize that both of you have valid feelings and perspectives. Your fiancée is curious about exploring new ideas, while you have a firm stance on what you want in a relationship. It doesn't necessarily make you an AH for not wanting to research open relationships, especially if it conflicts with your core values and beliefs.

However, it might be helpful to approach this situation with openness and empathy. Consider having a calm conversation where both of you can express your feelings and concerns without judgment. You might not be interested in an open relationship, but understanding her perspective and why she’s curious could help bridge the gap. It’s also an opportunity for her to understand your boundaries better.

Ultimately, compromise might not mean changing your relationship structure, but rather finding a mutual understanding and respect for each other’s views. Seeking couples counseling could also provide a safe space to explore these discussions with guidance.
claude_response:
No, you're not being unreasonable. This situation reflects a fundamental difference in relationship values, and you're being honest and consistent about your boundaries. While your fiancée is right that people can change their views over time, you're not obligated to research or consider relationship styles that you know don't align with your values.

The concerning part isn't just her interest in open relationships, but her reaction to your boundary. Calling you narrow-minded for maintaining a clearly stated relationship preference suggests she might be trying to pressure you into something you're uncomfortable with, rather than respecting your position.

This situation likely needs a deeper, honest conversation about what you both want from your relationship. If she's truly interested in pursuing an open relationship, and you're certain you don't want that, it may indicate an incompatibility that needs to be addressed before marriage. Consider couples counseling to help navigate this discussion productively.

Remember: standing firm on your relationship boundaries doesn't make you close-minded - it makes you self-aware and honest.
llama_response:
It sounds like you're feeling torn and uncertain about the current state of your relationship. On one hand, you're trying to be true to yourself and your feelings about open relationships, which you've made clear from the start. On the other hand, you're concerned about potentially losing your fiancée because of this disagreement.

I sense that you're not opposed to open relationships out of judgment or narrow-mindedness, but rather because it genuinely doesn't align with your values and desires for your relationship. It's understandable that you wouldn't want to compromise on this aspect of your relationship.

However, it's also important to acknowledge your fiancée's curiosity and desire to explore this topic. Her request for you to research it together might be coming from a place of wanting to deepen your understanding of each other and your relationship. This could potentially help you both better understand each other's needs and desires, and might even lead to a deeper understanding of your relationship.

Your fiancé’s curiosity is understandable, but it doesn’t automatically mean she needs you to change your mind or to research something you’re not comfortable with. title: AITA: For not wanting to see this guy again for comments he made

Tonight he was over and we were watching a movie and just talking and he made a comment about how when he was in the military that when he first became part of the infantry unit that women were not allowed to be in it and when he was leaving the military is when women were allowed to join. He made the comment that women shouldn’t be in combat because “we can’t made sound decisions during our period” and continued in saying that women shouldn’t be doing certain jobs because we can’t “lift” as much as a man. Like I understand that we may not be able to lift as much but that doesn’t mean we aren’t qualified to do the job considering plenty of guys do partner lifts.
