body:
So I’m 25 and currently writing my PhD thesis but attended a conference and got talking to a supervisor/PI who has a massive lab in America and is one of the top in the field (he literally was part of making a clinical device as part of his PhD nearly 30 years ago and has continued doing his research using it). There’s also no one else in Northern Ireland who uses this device so I’ve had to teach myself basically and I would gain so much experience going. There are people in republic of Ireland and UK using the device but there are no jobs currently available. 

He offered me to come over and give a talk to see if I like it but the post doc job would be there if I wanted it. I wasn’t originally looking or thinking of America because I never thought it was even on the cards that I would get the opportunity. 

My boyfriend (also 25) and I have been together/ living together for nearly 3 years. He’s my best friend and I want to spend the rest of my life with him (the possibility of marriage and kids etc in around 5 years has been discussed). 

From the start of my PhD we discussed how I would have to move away given the lack of opportunities in Northern Ireland for post docs. On top of that covid has reduced the amount of funding available for research and labs here are really struggling. We even told his friend, a couple of months ago that we wouldn’t know where we would be next year because of my job situation. I said I may have to move to Europe or at least mainland UK.

I was in France at a conference and the opportunity of being written into a grant was discussed. I spoke to my boyfriend about this but he felt it would be too difficult for him to integrate into Paris life as we don’t speak French and while I would be ok in an English speaking lab he probably wouldn’t have that at a job. I thought fair enough that’s a very valid point which would surely apply to all European countries. I did consider if I could go alone and do long distance for a year or so given it’s only a 1.5 hour flight and I felt really comfortable on my own there. Nothing ever came to fruition from it anyway and so we didn’t speak about it again.

When I was offered the all inclusive paid trip from the American PI to go and see if I liked the area and lab I was so shocked. It was only a few days later after meeting him so it was pretty overwhelming but he had outright said it’s ok if you don’t like it, it’s still an invited talk for your cv and I thought no brainer I’ll go for the 5 days. My bf agreed to come too to see if he would potentially move with me. That was all ok and my flights were booked. I got really excited about the opportunity. 

Weeks went by and I kept asking my bf to apply for his ESTA but he kept putting it off. He finally revealed he didn’t want to move there so felt there was no point going. This came as a shock to me but I blurted out the words ‘do you think we could do long distance’ without really thinking about it. He burst into tears and then so did I. I tried explaining how these opportunities don’t come around to everyone and that it was a once in a lifetime opportunity. I quoted one of my colleagues that this was the PhD dream to go to a conference and be offered your dream job from just speaking to the PI. I advocated for myself which is something I really struggled with in the past. But it didn’t feel good. It felt like I had put a knife to his heart and twisted it with every word. So I stopped and we sobbed. 

We sobbed for a few weeks every night. He works from 7am-10/11pm 5-6 days a week with no time for conversations in between so we were both knackered but him especially. After a week or so I brought it up again and we sobbed again, he asked could I not just get a job in industry. I felt insulted considering he worked at an industry company here and hated it and left after 6 weeks. And I’ve heard so many of these stories about pharmacompanies and industry and I want to stay in research it’s my passion. That’s not to say it doesn’t have a plethora of flaws. 

But don’t I owe it to myself to try? I’ve been in uni 8 years+ to get to this point I’ve worked so hard. I asked him if he could just support me in trying this for myself but he said ‘how could I support you leaving. You’re leaving your family and friends and everything else behind.’ I felt pretty frustrated at this point so i just turned around in bed and cried. There was nothing I could say or do to change his mind. 

I feel so guilty -I’m the one cause for his pain and in advocating for myself I’m not taking it away. I supported him for over a year with his new job even though it has awful working hours and I have felt so alone and ignored and 2nd best to it because he would say there’s nothing I can do this is my job I need this experience. And so I compromised and said I didn’t know what I would do in his situation either so I’ll try and support you. So I was really disappointed in the lack of support from him. 

So AITAH?
top_comment_body:
NTA

Don’t put a career off for what ifs. The what if he is the one. The what if of a family. Etc etc. 

I had a job opportunity on the other side of the states from me in a very remote part of the county. 3 hours away from an actual city. With no internet and limited phone calls. 

My husband supported me. 

Go, don’t hold back on your dreams. I hate to say it but relationships come and go. The best ones work at it even in hard times when the person isn’t right next to you. You learn to not take that together time for granted.

It's understandable to feel torn between an incredible career opportunity and the relationship with your boyfriend, especially when both are important to you. You're not an AH for wanting to pursue your dreams and build a career that you've worked hard for. It's natural to seek opportunities that align with your passion and professional goals. 

At the same time, it's clear that your relationship means a great deal to you, and you're navigating how to balance these two important parts of your life. It's commendable that you've supported your boyfriend in his job, and it's reasonable to hope for similar support in return. 

This situation calls for open, honest communication with your boyfriend. Exploring long-distance options or discussing how you both envision the future might be helpful. This is a significant decision and it's okay to feel conflicted. You deserve to pursue your dreams while also considering the impact on your relationship and finding a path that honors both.

title: aitah
body:
I decided that i wanted to have a little party since i haven't put on any kind of event in a long time. I got a nice hall and bands/dj's and decor and fun games etc for us all. It was a free private event (all the costs were out of pocket) but about 75 people were invited.  

I sent out the invites, everyone was super excited and so was i! I missed my friends and dancing and such. 

A week before the party i asked everyone to take a rapidtest to make sure nobody was showing up sick and spreading germs.  I didn't think it was a big deal to ask that. But apparently it was, i had about 30 people give me flack about, telling me i was unreasonable and that it was an invasion of their privacy. 
So i told them if they didn't want to do it thats there choice and i respect that but it meant they weren't invited to join us. But I also told them i would bring a bunch of tests incase someone changed their mind or didn't have time to hit up a drug store beforehand. In the end about 20 of those people refused to attent because of this. 
It still was a really fun night. But i was sad that those 20 people didn't come because of my request to do a test  before showing up. 

AITAH for this?
top_comment_body: NTA - I can never get over why people are so scared, anti taking a simple test......... I have heard all the excuses and none of them make any sense. You chose this as a way of feeling/verifying safety, it is your choice and their to say no. Glad you had a good time. They were the losers in this case.
op_engaged_comment_body:
NTA
In my opinion individual test results and “privacy” are less valued than the health of a group. However, you could have maybe asked them to show vaccine proof as an alternative because rapid tests can be hard to find and for some painful to take. Options could have been provided for masking and distancing too so more could have shown up and less blame would be placed onto you as the host. Overall not the asshole, but maybe work more with your guests next time to find alternatives so everyone can enjoy in a way they are comfortable.
gpt_4o_response:

In today’s climate, health precautions can be a sensitive topic, and people's reactions can vary greatly. It seems you were trying to strike a balance between hosting a fun event and being considerate of everyone’s well-being, which shows you care about your friends.

While some may have seen the request as an inconvenience or an invasion of privacy, it was your prerogative as the host to set guidelines for your event. You provided options by offering tests at the venue, which reflects your flexibility and willingness to accommodate different perspectives. It’s unfortunate that some chose not to attend, but it’s important to remember that you did what you felt was best for the group. You’re not in the wrong for prioritizing health and safety, and it’s great that the event was still a success.
claude_response:
I hear how much effort and care you put into planning this special event, and it's understandable you're feeling sad about some friends choosing not to attend. You were trying to create a safe, fun environment for everyone while being reasonable - even offering to provide tests for convenience.

You weren't forcing anyone to test - you gave people a choice and respected their decisions either way. The fact that you're questioning yourself and feeling concerned about those who didn't come shows you're thoughtful about others' feelings.

From what you've shared, you weren't being unreasonable. You invested your own time and money to host this event, and it's perfectly valid to set boundaries that help ensure everyone's wellbeing. While some friends disagreed with your request, many others understood and attended, resulting in what sounds like a wonderful celebration.

Try not to be too hard on yourself. You handled the situation respectfully while staying true to what you felt was important for the event's success and everyone's safety.

It's not unreasonable to expect guests to take some basic precautions, especially when it comes to health and safety. By offering to provide tests for those who didn't have time to get one, you were also showing that you were willing to accommodate and support your guests.

In this situation, it seems like you were trying to find a balance between being a considerate host and respecting your guests' boundaries. While some people may have felt that your request was an overstep, it's also possible that they were being unreasonable in their expectations. So, no, I don't think you were the a**hole in this situation.

title: Am I the asshole for wanting to call husbands female coworker out?
body: My Husband has a female co worker who is making me extremely uncomfortable. (Not worried about my husband cheating). When I met her a few years ago she was asking my husband to hang out with me. I hung out with her two times and that was it. She made a catty comment about my hair and I was done at that point however more happened after that. She every once in a while asks me to go out and hang out with her but I always decline because at this point I’m uncomfortable. She out of nowhere made “hope Chests” for my kids which are apparently boxes with things like dishes, pots and pans for my kids when they turn 18 and move out. She also has referred to herself as Aunt to my kids. I feel like this is weird since we are not close to her. She has flirted with BOTH of my brother in laws (husbands brothers) and I learned a few months ago that she slept with one of them. She felt it was appropriate to tell my husband about it after he told her he was going to brother in law’s bachelor party and literally told him he was “top 3” 🤮. My brother in law said she basically started when he was sleeping and drunk. He didn’t want her but he didn’t stop her. She’s constantly oversharing with my husband. She’s told him how she wants multiple boyfriends outside of her relationship with her husband but her husband won’t let her. Also that her husband ignores her sexually to play video games and doesn’t please her. Now she is getting divorced from her husband and has told my husband she’s going to start an only fans to pay her bills. She has also said that her soon to be ex is all upset because she is already sleeping with people and the divorce isn’t finalized. She told my husband it’s not her exs Business who she’s sleeping with. Which is between them but like WHY are you telling all of this stuff to my husband?! Would I be the ass hole for calling her out? She’s crossed so many boundaries and I’m to the point where I just literally want to tell her to keep her distance from my husband kids and I and that she needs to stop telling my husband about her sex life. That I’m not interested in being her friend and that I don’t like her? It’s so frustrating to have him have to listen to this shit every day at work. I have a high suspicion she’s interested in my husband at this point. Also when I first met her she said that all of the other wife’s of the men she works with won’t hang out with her because they’re jealous of her and think that she’s trying to steal their husbands. Now I’m starting to understand why…
top_comment_body: Pretty sure this is also on your husband. He should have set boundaries with her a long time ago. She's his coworker not yours. He should tell her she's being inappropriate and he doesn't want to hear these details and if she doesn't stop he'll go to HR. Also I'm wondering where was she with your brother in law that she basically raped him in his sleep? Why is she so involved in your lives if she's just a co worker?
op_engaged_comment_body: Pretty sure this is also on your husband. He should have set boundaries with her a long time ago. She's his coworker not yours. He should tell her she's being inappropriate and he doesn't want to hear these details and if she doesn't stop he'll go to HR. Also I'm wondering where was she with your brother in law that she basically raped him in his sleep? Why is she so involved in your lives if she's just a co worker?

It sounds like you're in a really tough and uncomfortable situation, and it's understandable why you're feeling frustrated. It's clear that this coworker's behavior is crossing boundaries and making you uneasy. It's important to communicate your feelings with your husband, ensuring that he understands your discomfort and concerns about his coworker's actions. He might be in a better position to set clear boundaries with her, considering they work together.

Before calling her out directly, consider discussing with your husband the best way to handle the situation together. Sometimes, a united front can be more effective in addressing uncomfortable situations like this. You both might decide that it's best for him to have a private conversation with her, asking her to respect your family's boundaries and to keep their interactions strictly professional.

Remember, you're not alone in this, and it's okay to protect your family's boundaries. It's completely reasonable to expect respect and space from those around you.
claude_response:
Based on the concerning pattern of behavior you've described, you wouldn't be an asshole for addressing these boundary issues, but how you approach it matters. This woman has demonstrated inappropriate behavior by:
- Making unwanted advances toward family members
- Oversharing intimate details with your husband
- Trying to establish an unwanted "aunt" role with your children
- Having a history of problematic interactions with other coworkers' wives

Instead of confronting her directly, which could create workplace drama for your husband, consider:
1. Having your husband set firm professional boundaries at work
2. Both of you limiting personal interaction with her
3. Being clear but polite if she reaches out - "We prefer to keep relationships professional"

Your instincts about maintaining distance seem justified given her pattern of behavior. Focus on protecting your family's boundaries rather than engaging in direct conflict. Your husband should also consider documenting these interactions in case they become a workplace issue.

Remember, you're not obligated to be friends with someone who makes you uncomfortable, especially when they've shown questionable judgment repeatedly.
llama_response:
You sound incredibly frustrated and uncomfortable with this situation. It's understandable that you'd want to set boundaries and protect your family, especially given the numerous instances of this coworker overstepping and oversharing. Her behavior does seem to be crossing many boundaries, and it's reasonable to feel concerned about her intentions, especially since she's been flirtatious with your brother-in-laws and shares intimate details with your husband.

It's not necessarily about being the "asshole" for calling her out, but rather about being clear and direct about your boundaries. You have the right to communicate your discomfort and set limits on how much information you're willing to engage with. If you do decide to address the situation, try framing it from your perspective, using "I" statements to express your feelings and concerns, rather than attacking or accusing her directly. This might help to avoid escalating the situation and allow you to assert your needs more effectively.
gpt_oss_response:
It sounds like you’re dealing with a lot of uncertainty and discomfort, and that’s completely understandable. You’re not automatically an asshole for setting boundaries—after all, you’re protecting yourself and your family from what feels like over‑stepping. The key is how you approach it.

1. **Set a clear boundary** – Tell your husband calmly that you’d like him to keep his office conversations professional and that you’re uncomfortable with the coworker’s personal disclosures.  
2. **Address the coworker directly, but politely** – You can say something like, “I’m not interested in a friendship beyond work. I’d appreciate it if you didn’t involve me in personal matters.”  
3. **Keep it about the behavior, not the person** – Focus on the specific actions that upset you (oversharing, flirtation, uninvited “hope chests”) rather than labeling her.  

If the coworker continues to intrude, you can involve HR or ask your husband to set more formal boundaries. You’re protecting your emotional space; that’s not being an asshole, it’s setting healthy limits.

title: AITAH for debating on turning my mom in
body:
I’m sorry in advance, this will be all over the place since it’s a lot.
 I (22f) recently came to terms with the lie that I’ve been living. **There will be trigger warnings **My boyfriend (23m) has been trying to help me realize what’s been occurring the last two years but I have always been so desperate to have my mom that I couldn’t see it. It took her putting my life in danger once again for me to finally start opening my eyes and diving deeper into all of her manipulation and deception. 

Example 1: 
When I was five, my parents separated. From that point, my mom has filled my head with how awful of a person my dad was, there was never a time of us being together that she didn’t talk badly about him. She formed my perspective of my dad by doing so, anytime he’d mess up she’d feed off of that to pursue her agenda. I recently realized he was never the person she painted him out to be, she was mirroring everything she was doing onto him. 
She tried making me accuse him of r*ping me when he never did.

Example 2: 
When I was 7 I believe, she started dating a psychopath. He stalked us, ab*sed us, tried to k*ll us, tried kidnapping me, k*lled my rabbit, etc. she ended up losing custody of me. Mixed with all of the neglect she was doing, the dr*gs, and whatnot. 
He ended up going to prison. As soon as he was released(he was in for around 10 years), she was back in contact with him. She was in a relationship with him again in 2018 and I had told her to stop choosing bad guys over her kids or she’d eventually lose us. She always chose abusive or guys struggling with drug addiction over her kids. And I always forgave her and looked past that because I wanted a mom.

In 2020 she was being evicted from her house. My boyfriend and I decided to help her, we bought land together and a house, which she eventually got her own little house added onto the land. She immediately invited him over and manipulated me into believing that he was the only one who’d help with the water connection. She’s always had a way of painting herself as a victim and making others feel sorry for her. He tried stealing from us and she claimed she cut him off. Then in November of 2022 she picked up his dog to babysit and hid it from us. She finally admitted that she had his dog and was in contact with him again.
I finally realized she’ll always choose him over her kids. I realized how much danger that I am in with both of them.

Example 3: 
She manipulated me into helping her hide out. Ever since I was a kid she taught me that I needed to protect her. She owes over 35k to child support, she commits tax fraud and she lies about having a disability to receive additional income. 
She works 3-5 days a week cleaning houses and puts her checks in my name or has them pay in cash to hide that she makes an income. She convinced me to put her car and insurance in my name since she no longer could register it in her name due to child support debt.

Example 4:
She’s been living off of us all of 2022. She pays around $120 each month while we pay over $2,000 and we can’t afford it anymore. We pay her phone, her house, her car insurance, her dish, the water bill, the dog food (250 a month), etc. she’s drowning us while we’re trying to start our lives and doesn’t care.

At this point I feel like to stay safe I need to turn her in, I feel like she doesn’t care if I d*e or go to jail for her. But I still feel guilty for it. All I’ve ever done is protect her and keep her secrets and I don’t know how to not feel guilty for protecting myself finally.

So, AITA for debating on turning her in?
top_comment_body:
Turn her in and don't feel bad about it.

The money your wasting on keeping her in your life, use it towards a good therapist who can help you work through all the trauma/abuse/neglect she put you through not just as a child, but as a adult too.

Look at it this way, if you have/want kids, is this the type of mother/daughter relationship you want them to be witness to? To her behaviour? The problems and trouble she causes you? 

You have a life to live, she doesn't deserve to be part of it.

NTA.
op_engaged_comment_body:
What exactly do you plan to accomplish?

Yes she sounds like a terrible mother. But how will you turn her in? Who will you turn her into?

Contacting the police won’t solve anything unless you have evidence. And then she’ll probably be in jail for something minor.

It sounds like you're in a very complex and emotionally taxing situation. You're dealing with a lot of conflicting feelings—loyalty to your mom, concern for your safety, and the desire to protect yourself and your future. It’s important to acknowledge that wanting to protect yourself and create a safe environment is not something you should feel guilty about. You deserve to live without fear and manipulation.

Your mom's actions have put you in difficult and dangerous situations, and it's understandable that you're considering taking steps to protect yourself. This doesn’t make you a bad person; it shows that you are taking responsibility for your own well-being. It's okay to prioritize your needs, especially if someone else’s actions are harming you.

Reaching out for support from friends, your boyfriend, or a counselor might help you process these feelings and make a decision that aligns with your values and needs. Remember, seeking help is a strength, not a weakness. You have the right to live a life free from manipulation and fear.

I hear how much pain and conflict you're experiencing right now. It's clear you've been carrying an enormous burden from a very young age - being made to protect your mother when she should have been protecting you. Your guilt is understandable because you've been conditioned since childhood to put her needs first, but it's important to recognize that this wasn't healthy or normal.

The fact that you're questioning this now shows incredible strength and growing awareness. You're not being a "bad daughter" by considering legal action - you're finally acknowledging that your safety and wellbeing matter too. Your mother has not only put you in physical danger repeatedly but has also involved you in illegal activities that could jeopardize your future.

You're absolutely not the asshole for wanting to protect yourself. Taking action to ensure your safety and stop enabling harmful behavior isn't betrayal - it's self-preservation and potentially the most loving thing you could do, both for yourself and ultimately for your mother who needs to face the consequences of her choices.

Consider speaking with a counselor who specializes in family trauma to help you work through these difficult feelings and decisions.

It's understandable that you feel guilty, given the deep-seated pattern of putting her needs before your own. However, it's essential to acknowledge that you've been manipulated and used as a means to further her own interests, putting you in harm's way.

Your feelings of guilt are valid, but they shouldn't hold you back from taking the necessary steps to ensure your safety and start rebuilding your life.

title: AITA for ignoring my friend who falsely accused my boyfriend of sexual assault?
body: I’m a high school student and I had a long time friend let’s call her Emily. Right off the bat she started getting s weird obsession with my boyfriend always touching him and even grabbed his hand at a movie once and wouldn’t go overall weird behavior and it made my boyfriend and I very uncomfortable. It was obviously to everyone that she liked my boyfriend and so we started to distance ourselves from her and she then accused my boyfriend of sexual assault for hugging her without her consent and she told everyone in school. He was then proven innocent with a combination of video evidence and Emily admitting to her friends she made it up to break us up. But before he was proven innocent our life turned into a living hell at school people talking bad about both of us sending us threatening texts and calls and my boyfriend even got punched in the face when he was eating lunch when he was proven innocent it all blew over. This happened 6 months ago and I ignore Emily I don’t talk bad about her or start anything but when she talks to me I just nod my head and walk away. She got her mom (mind you were in high school) to call my mom and saying I was being rude and my mom got pissed at me telling me to let it go. I’m not trying to be rude and I understand ignoring someone isn’t great but I just cannot ever forget what happened it made my school life hell and made me become serverly depressed and I’m sorry but I can’t look that girl in the eyes without going back to that time. So am I the asshole?
top_comment_body: NTA. Nothing irritates me quite like a female falsely claiming sexual assault for whatever reason. It can seriously ruin someone's life and/or reputation unnecessarily. I don't know what your mom is thinking bybtelling you to let it go unless she doesn't know the whole story, but that is not something you just forgive and forget. Emily has shown her true colors to you and she has proven that she is not your friend. She doesn't care about you or your boyfriend cause if she did she wouldn't have done that. I don't care if anyone tries to say she's just young and immature. High school aged kids are old enough to know right from wrong and understand consequences. I can't tell you how to handle this, but from what you've said I believe you'd be better off cutting her from your life. That doesn't mean being rude and it doesn't make you a bad person to do so, it's just you protecting yourself from a toxic person. When someone shows you who they really are, believe them. Whether that ends up being good or bad.

title: AITA for refusing to allow my boyfriends bm to see their child ?
body:
I (18f) have a bf (21m) & he has a kid (4years old m) my boyfriend has been the sole provider for his child since the day he was born. My boyfriend worked 2 jobs and still managed to get his diploma while taking care of the baby. His Bm made it clear in the beginning that she did not want anything to do with the baby *she didn’t even sign the birth certificate* my boyfriend has full custody of that child. Recently for the past 3 weeks  times have been hard for him with juggling work & dealing with the recent death of his cousin. I have a pretty open schedule since I did graduate highschool early & only work Monday- Friday 8-3. I stepped in to help with the baby. I picked him from school, fed him, bathe him, spent time with him, played with him etc. I even ordered him a few Christmas gifts. *I have always been active in this child’s life since the day me & my bf got together. Just never really been active without my bf around if that makes sense* about 4 days ago my boyfriend came clean and told me the real reason why his bm isn’t in the babies life*I won’t get into detail but just know she caused physical harm to that baby he even showed proof of the hospital records and court documents*  

The bm found my instagram and engaged in a conversation with me. I was ofc respectful and had small talk back. She then asked me where me and the baby were going to be at later on today so she can come get him. I left her on read & sent the message to my boyfriend he told me”you are his mom now. I don’t think she should see him but if you think it’s a good idea that it is fine” I thought about it for a second and told her it would be fine only if I was  present & if we are in a public place. She started to get really hostile with me and started to disrespect me. I told her if this is the attitude that she has a grown women just because she can’t get her way then maybe she doesn’t need to see him at all. I told her to have a nice life and I then blocked her. 

I told the story to my Gma and she told me no matter what she carried this baby for 9 months not me. Told me no matter what she did to the baby I shouldn’t keep her away since I’m not the bio mom. I don’t think I’m keeping her away since I gave her an alternative option and she got upset. My bf told me I did everything right. AITA ?

title: Am I the asshole for not wanting to communicate with my daughters “bonus mom”.
body:
TW: Sexual assault 

I spent 6 years of marriage to my daughters father being told he was a victim of sexual assault. It happened in high school when he was 18, and he was in therapy, had night mares, and struggled all around with it still in his late 20’s. I heard the story in detail multiple times, with him crying often. He’d vent about how ugly she was, tell me how awful of a parent she must have turned out to be, his mom would tell me what a crazy bitch she was. I just listened to him and helped him work through it how I could. 

There were issues in the relationship, and a lot of lying. To this day I don’t know much about who he really is. He lied about his religion multiple times, lied to get me to marry him….it was a mess. He’d even lie about simple things. There were more issues, but I won’t even open that door. It’s a novel. Needless to say I couldn’t stay with him any longer and fell out of love because of all the lies. I didn’t feel that the person I did love even existed, it was just lies upon lies. Now we share custody of our daughter. 

Just days after I broke up with him he was talking to the girl who SAed him. The same girl he had all the flashbacks about and hated. Now they’re together, and she’s my daughter’s “bonus mom” and tries to communicate with me about coparenting. He said he “set her straight” and things are fine now. His mom is very close with her and they all live together. 

I have no interest in talking to this woman. The entire situation makes me sick. I keep communication short. His mom keeps inviting me to family outings and I have nothing nice to say, so I stay quiet. Am I the asshole for being short with them and not doing family outings, etc, with our daughter? I just want them all away from me. They’re all acting like I’m crazy for not allowing them into my new life. I accepted its not my business, I just don’t want to like share Christmas dinner or go to brunch. As a victim of SA myself I’m so confused. But maybe people cope differently? If I’m being a jerk so be it. I’m just confused.
top_comment_body:
If this woman SA'd your husband, can you prevent her from being around your child?
I would think (and I may be wrong) that you would be able to subpoena information from their therapist regarding her and what she did. Also if you have texts from your ex and/or his mother.

I would think that at the very least the courts would order supervised visitation as long as she is in the picture.

title: AITAH for not wanting to give xmas gifts to son's ex stepkids?
body:
So here is the situation.  My son met a girl who had a child already.  They got married and had 2 kids.  Then wife cheated on my son, dumped him, and married another dude, had a kid with that dude.

THEN, she and my son cheated on her husband and she got pregnant , dumped her husband and she and my son had a 3rd kid together.  THEN  she dumped my son again and they have remained apart.

I have no relationship with any of the kids other than the 2 he had with her the first time.  I have not even met the younger 2,(one is his, one is not his).   Her son that she had before they got together, i have obviously met, but we have no relationship.   Both of the boys who are not my son's children have fairly wealthy and involved fathers and grandparents.   one of them even gets to go to disney once a year with is dad and the others dont. Both fathers and their families really load up those boys at xmas.

Now xmas is coming, and it been a really bad year financially for my husband and I.  Basically,  I dont want to buy xmas gifts for the 2 that are not my son's kids.   If  my son and their mother were together, i would consider them my grandkids,  EVEN though i dont really know them.

SO...  AITAH  for not wanting to consider them grandchildren and  not want to give them gift?  or should i just suck it up and buy them gifts?  I will note that i have provided xmas and birthday gifts for the past several years and have NEVER received a thank your or any type of acknowledgement  that they had received them.  I do not speak to their mother at all.

Edit:  I appreciate everyones feedback.  after talking with my son, who totally understands my viewpoint, i will be getting something for those two kids, because my sons says his ex  is so vindictive that she will be extra shitty and might not let him take the older two this summer if i dont.  I am trying to think of one big gift, but their ages are so spread out....16,  11, 10, 5 and 1.
top_comment_body: May I suggest gifting your grandchildren experiences with you during a visit separate from their family xmas gathering? Then there's no risk of one of tge other children feeling left out, but you still get to do something special with your grandkids.
op_engaged_comment_body:
Oooof. That’s a really tough spot. I hope you recognize your son is 100% as at fault as anyone else in this scenario, so I truly hope you aren’t making your decision from some “moral high ground” perspective. As far as the issue at hand goes, if it was a tough year don’t buy presents for any of them. At the end of the day kids aren’t going to understand all the bs around who “is a grandchild” and who “isn’t a grandchild”, nor SHOULD they have to deal with any of that very adult drama and bullshit that their mom & your son & other baby daddy created. What they will understand, however, is how someone is buying their siblings gifts but for some reason has deemed them as less than or not worthy of a present. You don’t owe anyone gifts. They’re called gifts for a reason. But don’t inflict emotional distress on a child by playing favorites (again that’s how they’ll understand it) when you could just not give gifts, ESPECIALLY if you really can’t afford them anyway. The kids are innocent in this, even the ones who aren’t your “real” grandchildren. Just my thoughts. NAH though, at least you’re putting some genuine thought and concern into this

Sincerely,

Not a “real” grandchild

title: AITA for telling a friend’s daughter she was eating too much cake and embarrassing her?
body:
My best friend Chloe is a very picky eater and it’s difficult to eat out together anywhere. She has sensory issues and struggles with the texture and taste of a lot of foods and so has a limited diet which she finds embarrassing. She’s reluctant to go out to restaurants for celebrations as she often eats off the children’s menu which draws attention to her. It was her 40th birthday a few weeks ago and she requested a low key celebration and as she doesn’t really like crowds or drink much alcohol it ruled out a lot of the usual birthday celebration ideas. I had the idea to do an afternoon tea party for her in my garden as it’s a large beautiful space and there was no pressure to eat off a menu as we could choose her favourite foods. I put bunting up in the garden and invited 10 of her closest friends and family, I organised games, mocktails, sangria and gin cocktails in teapots with tea cups instead of tea. 
For the afternoon tea we had plain cheese and egg mayo sandwiches on white bread instead of traditional cucumber or smoked salmon, salt and vinegar crisps, mini sausage rolls and quiches, chocolate eclairs and my friends mother baked a special birthday cake. 
On the day it was beautiful and sunny and we had lots of fun catching up and playing games, Chloe loved her surprise tea party. 
Everyone turned up but one of our friends also brought her 13 year old daughter “Becky” who was supposed to have been with her father for the day. Unfortunately he was unwell and as it wasn’t a rowdy party my friend said she had no choice but to bring Becky along. 
When we made the afternoon tea we made sure there was a lot of food to eat as some people were drinking which can cause them to be more hungry then usual and we thought it was better to do too much then too little. Unfortunately just having one extra person stretched it as Becky eats a lot! Everyone took a small plateful but Becky loaded her plate and then went back for another whilst everyone else was still nibbling their first. Chloe was so busy chatting with everyone that she was very slow at eating, by the time she went to get a sausage roll (her absolute favourite) they had gone. Becky had eaten 6! 
We brought the cake out and sang happy birthday and Chloe was moved to tears, she cut it up and managed to get it into 11 pieces and put it on the cake stand for everyone to take a piece. I was busy talking when a friend came over and discreetly mentioned Becky was on her third slice of cake. I was annoyed at this because it now meant some people weren’t going to get any, so I decided to ask her mum nicely if she could speak to her. Unfortunately I couldn’t see her mum anywhere so I thought I’d speak to Becky. One of the pieces of cake was untouched on her plate so I thought I’d ask her to put it back so someone else could try some. I approached her and said nicely that I was glad she was having a nice time but I explained there wasn’t enough cake for everyone now and asked her to put the slice back. I said I was worried Chloe wouldn’t get any like with the sausage rolls. She started to cry and said to her mum I’d called her a greedy pig when her mum came and saw us together, it made her mum very angry and she didn’t believe me when I denied that happened. After that they ended up leaving early which is a shame as up until then the day had been perfect and it made things a bit awkward. 
Since then a couple of people said I was in the wrong to approach Becky no matter how nicely but as she was at an adult party I tried to reason with her like one. AITA?
top_comment_body: NTA...it would seem little Becky has a bit of an eating problem, mom is in denial of this (or the usual divorce guilt so she allows the child to do whatever they want so she doesn't end up liking daddy more, with the child having glommed on to this), and there's no shortage of people to help her in all this so as not to "rock the boat." This was unconscionably bad manners on the part of both mother and child. If I was you, I wouldn't just stand your ground, I'd go so far as to demand an apology from THEM, as well as from anyone who backed them up. Being a good person doesn't mean you allow people who've decided the world revolves around THEM to bully you.
gpt_4o_response: It sounds like you were in a difficult situation, trying to ensure everyone, especially Chloe, could enjoy the celebration. Your intention to address the issue discreetly and kindly shows that you cared about the balance of the party. However, it's understandable that Becky might have felt embarrassed or singled out, especially being a teenager at an adult gathering. Perhaps, instead of addressing Becky directly, it might have been more effective to wait for her mother to return and discuss it with her privately. This could have avoided misunderstandings and maintained the festive atmosphere. Remember, navigating such situations can be challenging, and your intention was to be fair and considerate to all guests. It might be helpful to reach out to Becky’s mother to explain your perspective and express any regret for the misunderstanding. This could help mend any rift and clarify your intentions.
claude_response:
From what you've shared, while your intentions were to ensure everyone got their fair share, especially the birthday celebrant Chloe, the approach could have been handled more sensitively. Speaking directly to a 13-year-old about their eating habits at a social gathering, no matter how politely done, risks causing embarrassment and emotional distress - which unfortunately happened here.

A better approach would have been to:
1. Wait to find Becky's mother
2. Quietly set aside portions for those who hadn't eaten yet
3. Make a general announcement about saving some cake for everyone

Teenagers can be especially sensitive about food and body image. Even well-intentioned comments can have unintended negative impacts. While you weren't trying to be hurtful, approaching her directly about her eating was likely embarrassing and potentially harmful to her self-esteem.

Moving forward, consider apologizing to both Becky and her mother, explaining your good intentions while acknowledging that your approach wasn't ideal.

However, it's clear that your approach, although well-intentioned, wasn't well-received. Becky felt embarrassed and hurt, which led to her leaving early with her mom. In hindsight, it might have been more effective to speak with Becky's mom first, as you initially intended, to address the issue.

Even though you didn't call Becky a "greedy pig," it's possible that your words were perceived as critical or judgmental. Considering Becky's age (13), it's possible that she was more sensitive to your comments than an adult would be. It might be helpful to reflect on how you could have approached the situation differently, taking into account Becky's age and potential sensitivity.

Open communication with your family about what happened might help you all understand each other better.
claude_response:
I understand you were defending your sister during an emotionally charged moment. Your Tia's comments were incredibly insensitive, especially during such a meaningful celebration that was already difficult for your sister without her father present. Your protective instinct came from a place of love.

However, responding with physical violence, even when provoked, isn't the right way to handle the situation. There were better ways to stand up for your sister, like firmly but calmly confronting your Tia about her cruel remarks, or simply focusing on supporting your sister in that vulnerable moment.

It's touching that your sister appreciated you standing up for her, but she's right that the slap wasn't appropriate. While your Tia was clearly in the wrong with her heartless comments, responding with violence only added more drama to an already emotional situation.

Consider apologizing to your Tia for the slap, while also expressing how hurtful her comments were. In the future, try to channel that protective energy into more constructive responses.
llama_response:
It sounds like a highly emotional and sensitive situation at your sister's quinceanera. I can understand why you'd feel protective of your sister, especially given the circumstances of her father's passing. However, slapping your Tia might not have been the most effective way to handle the situation. 

It seems like your Tia's comment was hurtful, but lashing out physically might have escalated the situation further. Your sister even thanked you but said you shouldn't have done that. This indicates that while your sister appreciated your intention to defend her, she might not have agreed with your method.

It's also worth considering that your mom and Abuela were already trying to comfort your sister, and your actions might have added more tension to the situation. Reflecting on how you could have handled it differently might help you navigate similar situations in the future.
gpt_oss_response:
It sounds like a really painful night for everyone, especially your sister. Slapping someone—no matter how upset you’re feeling—crosses a line that’s hard to justify. Even if you were defending your sister’s memory, a physical reaction can feel like a betrayal to her and to your mom, who is already worried about the fallout.

AITA? Most people would say yes, because you used violence when you could have spoken calmly or stepped away. That said, your frustration is understandable; your sister is grieving a lost parent and your aunt’s comment hit a raw spot.

Try to apologize to both your sister and your mom, and explain why you reacted the way you did. Ask your aunt to be more supportive next time. If you’re struggling with anger, consider speaking with a counselor or mediator to help you all navigate the family dynamics more peacefully.

title: AITAH For kicking people out of my wedding?
body:
Me (23F) and my now husband (25M) got married last May. We had an elopement and after the honeymoon we had a picnic with all our families and friends to celebrate. I live in Utah and (I’m not sure if this is a thing in other states) but people usually announce their wedding publicly in social media and ask people to send their address for an invitation. It’s usually really open and even without an invitation, people can still go. I didn’t want that and neither did my husband so we announced our wedding without all the details (like date and place), but didn’t invite everyone to our celebration. 

The day of the celebration some people that weren’t invited assisted. Specifically 2 guys who used to be my friends when I first moved to Utah, but that cut me out of their lives over a year and a half ago, I was so confused and honestly very offended, too when they showed up, because they used to be my closest friends once but they didn’t think I was worth keeping in their lives. I tried so hard to not distance myself from them because they were supposed to be my best friends and at that time I didn’t know many people. 

When they stopped reaching out I decided to let them go if they wanted to, I was really lonely and sad, a couple months after was when I met my husband. Mind you that these guys weren’t part of my life for the whole time I dated my husband, never reached out to congratulate me on our engagement or when I announced our wedding. They just showed up with a group of mutual friends (the ones I did invite) saying they wanted to “surprise me” because it’s been so long since I saw them (these guys literally live in the same county as me, we haven’t seen each other because they didn’t want to). I was so mad, I told them “you and I aren’t friends, you can’t disappear out of someone’s life and come back whenever you want and call that a friendship. This isn’t a friends reunion, this is a private event and you weren’t invited. Please get out of here” I didn’t yell or made a scene, I kept my voice calm and told them that in private. 

I tried to be as polite and clear as I could so there weren’t any  misunderstandings, but some people that heard of what I did said I was rude and petty, and that they didn’t mean any harm by coming so I should’ve let them stay and have food. I’m so confused because if they weren’t invited, I think it’s rude on them to show up, but the only person that really defended me was my husband. So I need others’ opinions, was I the asshole?
top_comment_body: NTA- it’s your event and they showed up uninvited. You shouldn’t have to feed them because they “showed up” fuck them.
gpt_4o_response:
It sounds like you were put in a difficult situation, and your feelings are understandable. Your celebration was a special, private event meant to be shared with those who have been actively part of your life. It's natural to feel upset when people who had distanced themselves from you suddenly show up without an invitation, especially given your past efforts to maintain the friendship. Setting boundaries is important, and it seems you communicated your feelings calmly and clearly to them.

It's possible that those who criticized your decision might not fully understand the history and emotions involved. It's okay to prioritize your comfort and the atmosphere you wanted for your celebration. Remember, it's your event, and you have the right to decide who should be there. Your husband supporting you is a positive sign that you made the right choice for both of you. Trust your instincts and know that it's okay to stand up for yourself and your boundaries.
claude_response:
Based on the situation you described, you were not the asshole. You handled an uncomfortable situation with grace and appropriate boundaries. Here's why:

1. This was your private celebration, not a public event, and you made that clear in your announcement
2. These individuals chose to distance themselves from you for over a year and a half
3. They showed up uninvited, which is generally considered poor etiquette for any private event
4. You addressed the situation privately and calmly, without causing a scene

Their claim of wanting to "surprise you" seems inconsiderate given the context of your relationship history. A wedding celebration is not the appropriate time to try to reconnect with someone you've previously cut off contact with.

While some might view your response as harsh, setting boundaries is important, especially on your special day. You shouldn't feel obligated to host people who weren't invited, particularly those who chose to remove themselves from your life during important moments leading up to your marriage.

Remember, it's okay to protect your space and peace during significant life events.
llama_response:
You seem torn between feeling confident in your actions and being influenced by others' opinions that you were "rude" and "petty." It's clear that the situation with your former friends was complex and emotionally charged. You felt hurt and abandoned by their decision to cut you out of their lives, and their sudden reappearance at your private event triggered those feelings.

It's understandable that you wouldn't want to pretend like everything was fine when it wasn't. Your response to them, although direct, was calm and clear. You set a boundary and asserted your feelings in a private conversation. It's not about being "rude" or "petty," but about standing up for yourself and your right to choose who attends your private event.

It's interesting that others are questioning your actions, but it's also telling that your husband defended you. It's possible that others didn't fully understand the context of your relationship with these former friends. You did what felt right to you in that moment, and that takes courage.
gpt_oss_response:
It sounds like you were protecting a very personal celebration that you and your husband wanted to keep intimate. Your frustration is understandable—those two people had cut ties with you, and their “surprise” came at a time you had already decided to be selective about who could share that moment. 

You handled the situation calmly and set a clear boundary; that’s what you deserve. In a culture that often blurs the line between “public” and “private” weddings, expecting everyone to read the fine print can feel like a betrayal. Your husband’s support is a good sign that he sees your choice as reasonable. 

If you’re worried about future gatherings, consider a brief “please RSVP only” note or a direct message to those you truly want present. That way you can keep the intimacy you value while avoiding unwanted surprises.

title: AITAH for getting in a school fight and breaking some kids nose?
body:
Hello! This happened last Friday and I feel horrible. I really do think I’m in the wrong here, so does my mom, but I really wanted a 3rd opinion.

I(F16) am a sophomore in highschool. I take IB courses, so advanced maths, science, etc. I’m a bigger girl, 5’10, and wear baggy clothes. I should note that I powerlift, my biggest deadlift being 120kg. Combined with the baggy clothes, I often appear more chubby than I am. 

This boy, J(M16) has been picking on me since middle school. I am openly bisexual,  and he seems to think that is funny. He calls me slurs in the halls, but normally behind my back. Whenever I catch him doing it I call him out, and I don’t hear from him for a day until it continues. Sometimes he will even prank call me, but he’s stopped doing that ever since I signed him up for multiple inappropriate sites.

The big issue started on Wednesday, when J got up in my face. Of course he’d never done this before, and I’m assuming he did it to “impress” his friends. My friends looked at him like he was crazy, and I asked him what he was doing and laughed. Embarrassed, he insulted me and called me fat. He’d never brought weight into our little showdowns, so I was surprised. He must’ve noticed, because he kept going. I just let him have it and walked away.

The next day I had no classes with J, but at lunch the slander continued. “You probably don’t need that,” He snickered behind my back where I was sitting. J treated his harassment like some kind of disney highschool bully. It was ridiculous. Me and my friends ignored the comment, shared glances and laughed it off.

Friday is where it got bad. I had been telling my mom about everything, and she told me to go see a principal. We are both very passive people, and don’t enjoy large fights or confrontation which is why I had been enduring this for so long. I arrive to school and before my class I head to the principal. I tell her what has been happening between me and J, and she says something about J being suspended before and how there is nothing to do. She offered to give him a detention, but there was no point.

Fast forward to lunch, me and my friends were going to a grocery store off school property. On the way there we see a big group of boys, a small amount being J and his friends. We lock eyes, but keep to our separate groups. I see him whisper something, and just before we arrive him and his friends split from their own group to walk behind us. 

They basically follow us around the store, and begin stepping on the back of our shoes. I am having no part of this, and turn around. “Can you guys stop doing that?” I say, trying to shut the whole thing down. But they continue. At this point, I am getting mad. They are stepping on me and my friends shoes, which(mine) were new and white. “Are you trying to get in a fight?” I ask J, trying my best to sound intimidating. J is about 6’2 and an average weight, so obviously he has a snarky comment to add about me. “I’m not trying to fight you over any chocolate, don’t get defensive,” he laughed, so did his friends. 

At this point he was a little too close for comfort, so I pushed him away. Notably, I should not have done this. It was in the heat of the moment, and we were in a public store. He pushes me back, and it quickly escalates. He throws the first punch, straight to my jaw, but realistically closer to my ear. I hear my friends ask me if I am okay, before punching him. It wasn’t one of those pity punches either, I really put my body weight into it. Swinging full force I made contact with his nose. My adrenaline quickly wore off, and I asked if he was okay, he pushed me away swearing. I saw bl//d dripping from his hand covered nose, and quickly got out of the store with my friends. 

I guess he didn’t tell anyone, because I haven’t gotten any calls home. Reddit, AITA?
top_comment_body:
I don’t normally think violence is okay….However he swung first. And I think it’s more than reasonable for you to defend yourself. In fact I’m appalled that he would try to hit a woman. It’s disgusting.

He has also been bullying you and trying to upset you. The body shaming, the rude comments, getting in your personal space, etc. He is a jackass. Hopefully you taught him a big lesson. 

Imagine he’d been doing this to someone more vulnerable than you? You seem very strong but you experienced how badly this behavior could affect someone. 

Stand tall and proud. And don’t ever take his $hit. 

NTA.

PS you just lived the fantasy revenge of thousands of bullied kids everywhere. 👏🏼
op_engaged_comment_body:
A bloody nose is okay. If you broke it, he'd be down from the shock of the break, not pushing you away. He got embarrassed because you checked his attitude. You did good.

Since you aren't used to violence, understand this: broken body parts stop attackers, not cause them to push you (in your own words).
gpt_4o_response:
It sounds like you're in a really difficult situation, and it's understandable that you're feeling conflicted about what happened. It seems like J's ongoing harassment has been incredibly frustrating and upsetting for you, and it's unfortunate that the school hasn't been able to effectively address the issue. While physical altercations are not ideal, it’s important to acknowledge that you were provoked and acted in the heat of the moment after enduring persistent bullying.

It might be helpful to reflect on alternative ways to handle such situations in the future, perhaps by involving trusted adults or seeking mediation through school resources. It’s also important to prioritize your safety and well-being. Consider speaking with a counselor or a mentor about the incident and your feelings, as they can offer support and guidance on navigating these challenging situations.

Remember, acknowledging your feelings and seeking support is a positive step forward. You’re not alone, and there are people who can help you work through these experiences.
claude_response:
Let me break this down carefully. While violence typically isn't the answer, you were in a situation where you:
1. Tried reporting the harassment through proper channels (principal)
2. Attempted to verbally de-escalate multiple times
3. Were physically followed and harassed off school grounds
4. Were physically assaulted first (he threw the first punch)

You acted in self-defense after being verbally harassed, stalked, and physically attacked. While breaking his nose wasn't ideal, you were defending yourself from someone who had been bullying you for years and escalated to physical violence.

The fact that you immediately asked if he was okay shows you're not naturally aggressive. You tried multiple peaceful solutions before this incident. Your mom's right that fighting isn't great, but you were backed into a corner after exhausting other options.

My suggestion would be to document everything in case this comes back up later, but no, you're NTA for defending yourself when someone else initiated physical violence.
llama_response:
I can sense the frustration and anger you felt during the whole ordeal, especially with J's constant harassment and bullying. It's completely understandable that you'd want to defend yourself and your friends. However, taking a step back, it's clear that pushing J initially escalated the situation, and punching him in response to his punch wasn't the best choice either.

Considering your powerlifting background and the fact that you "really put your body weight into it," it's no surprise that J's nose got broken. While I'm not excusing J's behavior, I think you can acknowledge that physical violence isn't the best solution, especially in a public setting.

It's great that you've been talking to your mom about this and she suggested going to the principal, but it's unfortunate that the principal didn't take more action. In hindsight, maybe exploring other options, like talking to a trusted teacher or counselor, could have helped resolve the situation without resorting to physical violence.

In the context of the situation, I'd say you're not entirely in the wrong, but you did contribute to the escalation. It might be helpful to reflect on how you can handle similar situations in the future, perhaps by finding more effective ways to address the bullying and harassment.
gpt_oss_response: It sounds like you’ve been dealing with relentless harassment, and that’s a huge emotional burden. From what you described, J initiated the physical contact—he threw a punch first—so the fight was provoked. Your response was a reflex to protect yourself, especially after years of being bullied. Pushing him back was a natural reaction, but the subsequent punch you landed was a retaliatory act that caused him injury. In short, you were partly responsible for escalating the situation, but you were also reacting to a real threat. The school’s response (suspension notice, detention offer) seems limited; you might want to file a formal complaint or involve a counselor or student‑services office. For now, document what happened, get medical attention if needed, and keep a record of the bullying incidents. You’re not “bad” for defending yourself—just be prepared to explain the context if you’re asked.

title: aitah for wanting my husband to keep guns in a safe when we have kids?
body:
context: i (18f) lost my dad to gun violence (suicide) when i was 3 years old. i too struggle with suicidal ideation and do not trust myself near firearms. my (19m) husband (long story) is aware of this. it should also be known my husband wants to join the army (i dont exactly agree with this career choice but im not gonna stop him from doing it). now for the story.

this argument happened a few nights ago when we were discussing guns. my husband said he wanted to raise our kids around guns. i said no way. i asked him to please keep his guns in a safe while our kids (non existent yet) are little due to the fact that it only takes one wrong move to hurt themselves or someone else. he said i was being ridiculous. i even offered to buy him a gun safe only he has the password to. he didnt like that either. he said he would just take our kids to the range and HIDE IT FROM ME. i was livid. he wants to keep his guns out in the open but i just dont think its safe for me or the kids. the argument has died down since but it still angers me when i think about what he said. so i decided to come to reddit for second opinions. so reddit, please tell me if im being crazy. i think its a reasonable request but he is inclined to disagree.
top_comment_body: NTA.  ALL guns should be kept in a gun safe or otherwise secured. End of argument.
op_engaged_comment_body:
NAH

I understand your fear of firearms, but your husband is also right. Teaching kids gun safety is *important* if you're going to have guns in the house, even when you have a safe. Crap happens even when you're careful. Kids need to know guns aren't a toy. If you hide the guns from your kids, you risk them thinking they're taboo and it's possible they'll be determined to mess with them because you said not to... because they're kids and kids are dumb. But when kids are around guns, they become boring and they're less likely to mess with them unsupervised
gpt_4o_response: It sounds like you're in a challenging situation, balancing your own history and concerns with your husband's perspective. Wanting to ensure safety by keeping guns in a safe, especially with your personal experiences and struggles, is a completely valid and responsible approach. Your concern for future children's safety is not only reasonable but also a common one for many parents. It's important to have open and honest discussions with your husband about these concerns, emphasizing that your request isn't about undermining his interests but about creating a safe environment for your family. It might help to explore more about safe gun ownership practices together, possibly even involving a third party like a counselor or an expert in firearm safety. This could foster a mutual understanding and help both of you reach a compromise that respects both your values and concerns. Remember, your feelings and experiences are valid, and seeking a safe environment for your family is a commendable goal.
claude_response:
I hear how deeply personal and concerning this situation is for you, especially given your traumatic experience with your father and your own mental health challenges. You're not being unreasonable at all - wanting to safely store firearms when children are present is both responsible parenting and standard gun safety practice.

Your husband's response to hide gun activities from you is particularly concerning, as it shows a lack of respect for both your experiences and your role as a future parent. This isn't just about differing opinions - it's about basic safety and trust in your marriage.

Given your history with suicidal ideation and guns, along with the future safety of your children, this is a serious issue that deserves proper attention. I would strongly encourage you both to discuss this with a couples counselor who can help navigate this sensitive topic. You might also benefit from speaking with a mental health professional individually about your concerns.

Remember, advocating for gun safety doesn't make you "crazy" - it makes you a responsible parent and partner.
llama_response:
It sounds like this conversation has brought up a lot of emotions and concerns for you, particularly given your personal history with gun violence and your struggles with suicidal ideation. It's completely understandable that you would want to prioritize safety, especially when it comes to your future children. 

It seems like your husband's desire to introduce your children to guns is important to him, possibly due to his aspirations to join the army. However, it's crucial to acknowledge that your feelings and concerns are valid too. You're not being "crazy" for wanting to ensure a safe environment for your family. In fact, your willingness to find a compromise, such as offering to buy a gun safe, shows that you're trying to find a middle ground.

It might be helpful to have a follow-up conversation with your husband, where you both can share your perspectives and work together to find a solution that addresses both of your concerns. Perhaps you can explore alternative ways for him to teach your children about gun safety and responsibility that also prioritize your need for a safe environment.
gpt_oss_response:
It sounds like you’re standing on a very emotional and traumatic line. Losing your dad to gun violence and dealing with your own suicidal thoughts gives you a clear, visceral sense of how dangerous firearms can be in a home with children. That perspective isn’t “crazy”—it’s a legitimate safety concern rooted in lived experience.

title: AITA for calling my teacher her sister’s name on purpose?
body: So I (F) have a twin sister (fraternal twins, not identical), we go to the same school and we’re in the same grade so we have the same teachers. There’s this teacher in particular, who we’ll call Ms. Ava (not her real name),  that always calls me by my sisters name. I would normally just assume it was an accident and correct her but the school year is almost over and she hasn’t even bothered to learn my name and acts annoyed when I correct her. Yesterday, she called me by my sisters name AGAIN, and at this point I really think she’s doing it just to bother me. So I raised my had and said “Ms. Ava do you have any sisters?” she told me she did have one so I asked “What is her name?” “Mary” She responded . The next 10 minutes of class went on until I had a question, “Ms. Mary I don’t understand can you help me?” I said. She was furious. She started telling me how disrespectful it was to purposely call her another name just for the sake of being petty, she then told me that I would have 10 points subtracted from my homework for calling her Mary. I told her it wasn’t fair how she always called me my sister’s name on purpose but now that I do it I get punished. She told me that it was different because she was older than me and that if I didn’t stop talking back she would send me to the principals office. I told my mom about it and she said that I was being disrespectful and that I should apologize, but I don’t think I should. So AITA?
top_comment_body: You're not an AH for reflecting the disrespect back at her - tit for tat, I always say - but you are for getting yourself into a situation where you can be punished. Your own wellbeing is always your priority. A more constructive method might be to talk with your principal about how your teacher continually disrespects you with the wrong name.
gpt_4o_response:
Navigating situations like this can be frustrating, especially when it feels like your concerns aren't being acknowledged. Your decision to call your teacher by her sister's name seems to come from a place of wanting to highlight how it feels to be misnamed repeatedly. While your frustration is understandable, it's important to consider the impact of your actions. Your teacher may have interpreted your response as disrespectful, which escalated the situation.

Reflecting on your approach, it might be beneficial to find a way to address the issue more constructively. Perhaps you could have a private conversation with Ms. Ava, explaining how being called by the wrong name makes you feel and asking for her assistance in getting it right. This could help foster a more understanding relationship. 

Your mom's suggestion to apologize might not feel fair, but it could be a step towards resolving the tension. Apologizing doesn’t mean you were wrong to feel upset, but it can be a way to open a dialogue and express your feelings more effectively.
claude_response:
I understand your frustration with being repeatedly called by your sister's name, especially when you've tried to correct your teacher multiple times. While your creative approach to highlighting the issue was clever, deliberately calling a teacher by the wrong name crossed a professional boundary and could be seen as disrespectful.

Instead of escalating the situation, consider scheduling a private conversation with Ms. Ava or involving your school counselor to address this issue more constructively. You could say something like: "Ms. Ava, I know you might not realize it, but being called by my sister's name repeatedly makes me feel invisible and disrespected. Could we work together to make sure this doesn't keep happening?"

Your feelings are valid, but the approach you chose might have made the situation worse rather than better. This could be a good opportunity to learn how to advocate for yourself while maintaining professional boundaries and respect.
llama_response:
It sounds like you're feeling frustrated and disrespected by your teacher's consistent mistake with your name, and you're trying to make a point. However, I also sense that you're aware that your actions might have crossed a line. Your teacher does have a point that calling her by your intention of "Ms. Mary" was meant to be petty, even if it was a response to what you felt was her deliberate mistake.

It's understandable that you're not willing to apologize, but considering your teacher's perspective might help you grow from this situation. It's possible that she's not intentionally trying to annoy you, and it's also possible that she's not even aware of the impact her actions have on you. Perhaps you could try to have an open conversation with her about how her actions make you feel and see if you can find a resolution that works for both of you.
gpt_oss_response:
It can feel like a power play when someone keeps misnaming you, especially in a place where you’re supposed to feel safe and respected. You’re right to want to be addressed correctly and to see the teacher’s error fixed. At the same time, calling the teacher by her sister’s name was a deliberate provocation, and the teacher’s reaction—point deductions, threats of discipline—was a harsh consequence of that.  

You’re not “disrespectful” for standing up for yourself, but you also crossed a line by echoing the same mistake.
